39196746.review: Nothing can do this game justice like playing it for a long assssss time and getting lost in it. I love that different planets seem to have different length rotation cycles, as being on the dark side of a planet can make things a little more frustrating. The idea that one can customize any part of one’s ship to fit their needs is amazing. I can make my ship literally seem like I’m in a flying invisible cube from the inside, so you can see everything outside around the ship like a one-way mirror, should you so desire. Never had any complications with the controls, just give it a few hours to get familiar with. The lights from your character and ship react different on which ever planet you are on. Hit those lights on Morena (Ice planet) boom, you can see for miles all day as the surface seems to glow vibrantly. Hit the lights on Perun (Dark gloomy purple mountain planet) boom, your assss is almost still flying blind. Another trait about this game is that your character has the ability to leave your ship while it is still in motion (Both the pilots chair or the physical ship). To leave the pilot chair at break neck speeds can be really cool visually from inside the ship. The fighting system is fun, I feel with the damage output from the Xeons (Alien bad dudes) and the unlimited ammo pair in a fair manor. The sound track has my assss in a tranquil trance as I space the fuke out in space, truly amazing. The game overall has a load of potential and I can’t help but keep coming back even after I have finished the available story thus far. Things that would be nice to see in the future would be things like boarding enemy ships both active ships, and destroyed ships (Which I believe is in the works to some degree). Different weather fitting to different planets, as this would make locating something on a planet surface crucial to time or location in general. And also, the personal flashlight to transfer seamlessly from inside the ship to a planets surface, as one will need to quickly turn it off and on again to activate the lighting on the planet surface. Overall this game is hours of endless fun. Come visit the Zorica System

39173263.review: love it, very impressive and fun

39172632.review:
*** A small note after completing the story ***
**************************************************
Oh man. Just... WOW !
This game is amazing ! Well not the game itself, but the story is crazy addictive.
I bought the game today and I was not able to let go off of it until I finished the story. Took me about 8 hours.
I litterally did only that today, that and eating some junk food.
****************

Here is my review : 

PROS : 
--------
• Story is incredible, as long as you read everything and you imagine the 'movie' in your head. It's like reading a really good book, you can see the story in your head, see what happened and imagine the characters... This is exactly that. And it is very addictive too. I didn't get emotional but you feel the story, you feel how the characters feel. I got very attached to the characters of the first chapter.

• The technology behind the game is well done. Planets are orbiting the star and also rotating. There seem to be a real orbital mechanic into the game. When you are on the surface of a planet or an asteroid, you can see the enemy ships orbiting above you. Really nice.

• You can land on anything; Planets and Asteroids seemlessly. No loading, nothing 'poping' in existance. When you look at the surface of a planet from space, this is exactly what you will see once you get closer.

• You can move inside your ship even when it is moving. You can get out of the ship, anytime, any where. Even in space. You can float around and navigate with your jetpack. You can get inside wrecked ships scattered around the system.

• You can design the inside of your ship quite easily. It's fun to create your own design and then walk around your own ship. Also, if you do 3d modeling with Bender, well you can create your own ship model. But I don't so... it is still a pro, for those who can.

• Many more pros I cannot think of right now.


CONS : 
----------
• I don't really like the 'Low Poly' style games. I wish the dev, at some point in the future, will upgrade the visual quality of the game to make it more HD. But I guess this is the style the dev wanted to give it. Anyway.

• Very repetitive. It is alway the same. That is why I mostly played the story. Didn't do much else because there isn't much else to do. You can kill enemy ships, it is fun. But quickly becomes boring. And on the surface's markers, there's always a few enemy ground units. You can land and kill them with your gun, or park your ship above them and destroy them with your ship's weapons. Either way, every single marker is the same thing.

-------------------

If you are still reading, I strongly recommend you to try the demo. I did install the demo, and maybe 20min later I bought the game. Like I said, the story is very very good as it is, and with futur updates it will get even better.

The story alone is worth the price, and I can't wait to see what's next for this game.

End of my review.

---
Message to the dev :

I know you work mostly by yourself and it is a lot of work to pull off a game like this. But maybe it is time to hire more people. Because this game is awesome, but it is empty. You need to add so much more stuff to do,  more planets (with more details), variations... even consider a multiplayer feature.

I really enjoy the game so far, can't wait for Chapter 3 and beyond !

38917964.review:
So I've noticed there aren't many 'real' reviews of this game, so I'll take a jab at it, and I'll update it as I play.

Rodina is a space exploration/fighting game, with a story told through text, which you can fully throw yourself into, or just read the necessary bits and move along.

This is not a survival game, you don't gather resources, you don't build a base.
Although, you can customize your ships interior layout.

The space fighting is amazing, and it's super simple. I use a mouse and keyboard and it works great.
The controls for flying are great for me, although I haven't played many flying games.

The FPS is amazing, in this case I mean first person shooting, but framerate is also amazing thanks to the simple nature of everything.

Alright Pros & Cons.

Pros:
-Lasers (Pellets? Bullets? Idk) make a satisfying thud in fps combat.
-The controls are great.
-The graphics feel like they are from the PS2 era I'd say, which I really like, but some may not.
-The solar system is huge, with 4 gigantic bigger-than-earth planets, 50 large asteroids, and 40,000 small asteroids! (mind you, they are still quite a decent size.
-The guy who made this is a pro.
-The music is... amazing. Just, amazing.
-Retro mode makes the game look like a classic arcade game.
-Gravity bike or whatever it's called is amazing.
-You can take some great screenshots. (Check out mine!)

Cons:
-Game is only made by one person, so don't expect updates super often.
-Not a whole lot to explore on planets, but it seems like that's being worked on!
-The scale of everything is scary, like, you feel weird knowing that these planets are bigger than the earth we live on.
-
-
-

Just buy it.

38765451.review: One hour in and im already in love with the game, even though the game can be considered pretty much bare bones, it still gives all players a sense of grandess and mystery. From the simple things like depressurizing your ship and walking out leading to the planets unique soundtrack bring played and getting completely immersed in the atmosphere to the well done dog fighting in the atmoshpere and space, the game achieves greatness. Other little details left by the game developer also add a small sense of humor while exploring. An example would be the little data chips that can be found randomly on astroids and planets that give highly condesending advice ranging from teaching you how to breath air to survive to building highly complecated terraforming systems using grade 1 level language. Then you get to the on foot exploration and mechanics, and ive got to say, getting out of your speedy ship and starting to walk around and seeing how little objects move on the planets really gives you a sense of scale. This very sense was what sold this game to me, ive rarely ever seen it happen before in a game (skyrim was the other) and simply got blown away by it. Overall, a decent game, the developer is always making improvments and is willing to listen to the community, so make sure to pick this game up if you have a bit of money left over from the steam sales and are looking for something new. Any money towards this wonderful and ambitious project would be great I can imagine.

37909363.review:
Very bare bones at the moment, I bought this way back in 2014 so I have a lot more hours than the steam version shows here & there's been a few cool changes here & there but nothing substantial enough to make me want to recommend this game based on content alone, but if you're looking for a small indie space romp then this is certainly a promising game that hopefully will have much more in the way of content in future itterations. 

Pros: 
-Space exploration & massive planets to land & explore

-While still bare bones the flight mechanics are fairly solid

-Customizable ship interiors (not a lot of useful stuff to add from what I've seen, but it's a nice touch)

-Awesome soundtrack makes exploration a soothing experience

-Pretty cool sci-fi vibes, especially when landing in massive planetary vistas & seeing just how small you are

-Pressurized ship interior (not exactly space engineers level of cool, but still makes you be sure you closed the airlock...)

-Space physics (IE Asteroids spinning about as you try to land on them)

-Interesting graphical style, though feels somewhat dated in places (see cons for elaboration)

-1:1 planetary scales, you literally can get lost for months on these truly massive celestial bodies, and this really becomes apparent as you approach geological features such as mountains & valleys.

Cons:
-Both ground & ship combat feels unfinished & sluggish (I've heard of people who enjoy the combat in this game, so 
different strokes for different folks I guess)

-General lack of content to engage players for long periods of time (though obviously a lot more is planned for the future, so I'd say it's worth waiting)

-Feels limited being set in only 1 solar system. While the scale is large enough on it's own, I feel that there wasn't enough variety of planets to warrant further exploration (Was my experience a while ago I'm going off, so if I'm wrong here let me know & I'll correct the review)

-Poor lighting on models in certain situations & occaisonal muddy graphics (Can't help but feel that when I land a ship on a planet, that nothing is being reflected off or onto my ship, and the same goes for weapons too) although being an indie title going for a more primitive graphical style I can't hark on about this too much) 

-Bugs aplenty! But this goes for most Early Access games, so it's not really worth mentioning them outside of a bug report.

In summary this is an interesting little game if you're into that cool sci-fi "one man & his ship" setting, and the gameplay is (supposedly) intended to flow a little similar to older Elder Scrolls games, so this is definitely a unique title to keep your eye on, or purchase if you wish to support the developer (Who's just 1 guy on his own, and a pretty cool guy going off my interactions with him in the past)
If I got something wrong in the review, feel free to let me know & I'll make corrections according.

6/10 Interesting experience

Но данный товарищ за три года разработки добился большего нежели те же Hello Games куда большей по размерам командой да ещё и под патронажем SONY. В Rodina если ты летишь с края системы до её центра ты можешь наблюдать прохождение планеты по орбите вокруг звезды. Можешь поставить метку на любую точку в звёздной системе и долететь туда в несколько мгновений используя гипердрайв, а можешь исследовать систему неспешно: астероид за астероидом(благо их тут несколько тысяч всего-то). Можешь брать на абордаж корабли ксеносов и открыв шлюзовую камеру выкинуть весь экипаж корабля в открытый космос(правда злобных пришельцев это не убьёт, но игровой процесс разнообразит изрядно)и вступить с ними в совершенно нереалистичную перестрелку. Ты можешь приземлившись на поверхность планеты быть атакованным патрулём инопланетян и запросто остаться без корабля и тогда здравствуй загрузка автосейва и отвисшая от удивления челюсть. Планеты... Невероятно круто сделан вход в атмосферу: можно лишиться корабля сгорев в верхних слоях атмосферы и никакой огнетушитель не спасёт, хотя может спасти открытие шлюзов ... В игре многое сделано за эти три года:но как же многое предстоит сделать нашему герою-разработчику. Дай ему Бог удачи и терпения, а также единомышленников побольше дабы работа над игрой протекала веселее. У меня всё.

36032587.review:
The majority of the games that I play are open-world. This is likely the case for many people; to see a particularly eye-catching landmark or building in the distance and not be able to go there is a grave sin in my eyes, especially in this day and age, where advances in technology have made an expansive, vibrant world expected.

But no game I have ever played truly compares to the vastness of Rodina. True, the planets are anything but vibrant at this point, and the same enemy ships appear over and over, but all that pales in comparison to what can be seen in the game now: potential for something truly great. The developer has confirmed that alien structures will be implemented, and I can only imagine how the story will progress from its current, unfinished state. 

There is something done completely right, though, and that is the sheer size of the Zorica system. In making it the developer has created something fantastical, but what is, beyond the rapid and brutal orbital dogfights, faster-than-light transit, and speeding over the flats of an alien world on an anti-gravity bike, a very accurate representation of something that could very well be in our own cosmos. This is the universe we live in: a realm of terrifying distances, which can normally only be traversed slowly and with great care. Were the aliens and salvage sites removed, this would be something close to a spaceflight simulator. 

Explore a star system. Fight aliens. Recover snippets of data, pieces of a story of an Earth that has fallen into opulence and eschewed progress for the sake of comfort, and a hopeful few who dare to venture to the stars to escape that grim reality.

Welcome to the Zorica system.

I hope that game's developer will not get stuck with polishing the cover when the true diamond - the story line - awaits to be taken care of. I hope this pamphlet will turn into an epic saga.

35201238.review:
This game is quite fun.  As of right now, you can literally build the interior of your entire ship, and the game comes with neat ways to customise existing textures by altering colors, and customisable lights.  Flying the ship is fun and intuitive, even though it has no inertia dampening, it's easy to control.  The only thing that DOES get annoying is the clutch.

  The story is entirely optional.  You can fly around wherever you want, although being limited in the beginning to an asteroid field if you don't progress in the story.  The logs you can find are entertaining, and well written, as well as being in an easy to read font, especially as someone with minor dyslexia.

  Planet rendering is fast, with decent heightmaps and terrrain that doesn't get too ridiculous in shape.  Atmospheric lighting looks brilliant, and the art style of the game itelf is pleasing to look at.  Planetary textures aren't too shabby either, and the lighting from ship spotlights or the players flashlight has a really nice distance, and quite a large area of illumination.  One of my favorite features is the holoscreen, which lets you turn any room on your ship into a viewing area, foregoing a standard cockpit view, though I suppose the pilot station fills that role.

  The ship interior customisation is very similar to Doom Builder, if anyone reading this has ever used it.  You can make up to 7 floors, although 2 are quite tiny.  The interior space is quite large, you can make your ship a maze, a small cube and an airlock, or, if it suits your style, a rather phallus shaped cockpit "wink wink."  It's an easy to use system, with a decent amount of options.
  
  Combat is a bit easy, but I think it is mostly because of the really slick control scheme.  It's very easy to get your ship to do what you want it to.  The combat will likely get more diverse too, and the ship guns and even the fps guns, limited as both are, feel good to shoot.  The devs update relatively frequently, and the game is by no means dead.  They even comment on reviews!  Furthermore, they even try to help with issues a player might have.

  The UI is easy to read and clicking on things is crisp and responsive.  Performance is nice and smooth, with tons of graphical options to suit your needs and preferences.  The controls are concise and well developed, there doesn't feel to be any artificial smoothing or acceleration, which is a welcome change from all the games with forced smoothing, accel, or even, UGH, negative acceleration.

  TL;DR, if you like space exploration and combat, pick this game up.  This is 15$ that is well worth it IMO.

34882932.review:
Buy it now before it becomes a 60$ AAA game. This game has serious potential. 

Don't even worry about hardware requirements: you can lower the resolution (not size of the window, the pixel count) to actually be an 8 bit game. Every graphics setting is togglable. 

The gameplay is absolutely fantastic. The story and the lore is wonderful. It has the pros of AAA games (large open world) and none of the drawbacks (shoving every detail in your face). 

The spaceship centered gameplay/movement/combat is superb. Nailed it right on the bullseye. 

The score compliments everything so well. The combat theme gets your heart pumping even faster in the already intense contention between you and that squadron of enemy ships.

The out of spaceship combat... is in development... but the movement and the scale of planets gives you a feeling of euphoria as you uncover supply drop after supply drop.

The spaceship customization I only used for a huge deck where I could see the massive expanse of space around me. It's breathtaking, even in a low resolution.

TL;DR: Those few hours you may spend on this game might be short, but they'll be quite enjoyable. That's coupled with the fact that this game is still in development. Buy.

34799911.review: Rodina is a vast and enjoyable space exploration game that incorporates an awesome sense of scale and setting into a great experience. The space combat section of the game is generally pleasing to play and I found shooting down Xeno aliens rather satisfying, however the first person combat on the surface of planets can be a little clunky at times. But, I have faith this will be smoothed out in upcoming releases. Rodina is an intensely atmospheric game and the music score is brilliant, giving a sense of a heroic space rogue. I was enchanted by the sudden atmospheric change, especially in the game's score as I came across the planet Morena for the first time, and this only become more magical as I decended to it's surface, accompanied by the soundtrack. The planet's themselves, despite the game's retro style graphics are absolutely huge and lose no detail in the process, with winding canyons, plains and mountains included. Even a terrain glitch I found looked majestic. In all a great space exploration game that should get more attention and I am excited for it's potential in the future, what this already strong game could turn into after early access. Definitely a good buy.

33822921.review:
Honestly this game is easily in the running for best game ever made, it's solodev and still somehow manages to be better than even entire AAA titles.

Currently (at the time of writing) there is:
-literally 1:1 scale planets to explore (FOUR OF THEM!)
- Proper space combat with newtonian physics so you have to juggle aiming at the enemies and dodging and not drifting off away from the enemies
- FPS sections that feel REALLY satisfying and look like they're taken straight from a metroid prime title
- No Loadscreens, everything is streamed straight from the disk (be that in an airlock when moving into a ship or as you're travelling between places) and it really doesn't seem to affect anything to do with the performance.
An in depth story that may or may not be mostly finished, but if what i've seen this dev do is a good idea of his effort, it's huge AND unfinished (in a good way)
- Actual regular updates that aren't just bug fixes but tend to only add a few small things at a time (this is honestly a much better idea for a game like this because it means the dev can get feedback on each change rather quickly, instead of pushing a huge update that changes a lot of stuff that might take hours or days for the community to properly test).
- Like straight up ship interior design, loads of it!
- Complete difficulty options, in case a certain aspect is too hard for you, but you don't want to lessen other aspects of the game.
- you won't get literally everything done in any reasonable amount of time, this game just has too much to do in one sitting (not that that's in any way bad)

literally the only negative i have is that occasionally it bugs out, but these bugs are almost always fixed quickly due to a rather active community that isnt salty as all hell over not getting some features that they want (or maybe those people just up and left early on in development but still, they aren't around anymore at least.

overall, like infinity/10 perfect example of game development done right.


Just make sure you switch over to the dev beta branch in the properties menu on steam, then you'll get all the proper updates as they come.

Summary of my first life in Rodina

Started the game. Moon walk/jumped my way over to my ship. Took off and flew around the asteroid belt until I unlock cruise speed and then get what I need to warp drive around the solar system. Skip some more exploration and jumping around I come up to my first planet. Nearly burn up in the atmosphere (im not a very good pilot) only to find that the planet is so cold that its freezing my ship. Move on to another planet; once I get into atmosphere there is a squad of scouts waiting for me. "I can take six scouts, I've fought single and double scouts before really easy so six must be possible". 

Got eviscerated, managed to take two of them down with me before the engines gave out. In a blind panic I jumped up from the pilots seat, ran through the fires that had started all across my crashing ship, scrambled into the airlock and jumped out. Because my ship died way up in the atmosphere I ended up falling for a solid 3 or 4 minutes before finally falling back to the planet. The battle happened so far up that the ships attacking me are ignoring me now. After a good 20 minutes of hiking around the planet I finally found the burning wreck of my ship. In a weak final resort I tried to use the fire extinguisher on it. 

It didnt work. And now Im shipwrecked.

10/10

32751248.review:
This game is wonderful. The developer made so many smart design decisions. The music enhances the gameplay experience and sets a tone of adventure, wonder, and potential danger. The design of the ship is charming and believable, as it originally had a sizeable crew. And the holographic viewscreen design is gorgeous. 

The tutorials and explanations are very clear, although initially I didn't understand that the ship had default weapons other than missiles I picked up as this wasn't indicated but it's a minor oversight. I also enjoy that the ship's health regenerates after not taking damage for a time. This signalled to me that the game would focus more on adventure and exploration rather than wasting the player's time gathering resources, like in many other open world exploration games. 

The ship to ship combat is fun and intuitive and I also liked the fps combat. Fighting in a low gravity environment with a deep space background against multiple jumping enemies reminded me of some of the best parts of unreal tournament (in terms of the atmosphere; I don't mean to imply the gunplay is as nuanced as a more narrowly-focused fps would be expected to be). Also, the writing seems solid thus far. Each entry doesn't read as being from the same voice, even if it was written by the same author, which is a plus for immersion.

I recommend this game to anyone who is interested in a fun and easy to get into sci-fi/space exploration game with great atmosphere and honestly fun gameplay.

32412724.review:
Now I won't usually review early access games, this will probably be the only one, I also apologize for my poor grammar.

Now since that is out of the way let's get on with the review.

Rodina is a space exploration game that currently is barebones in terms of content but is being worked on by a very kind and surprisingly responsive developer. The core game it's self right now is as follows. 

[h1] GAMEPLAY [/h1]
     The gameplay in Rodina Is, as of now, mediocre for a space game. You can land on asteroids and planets, or burn up like I did and be amazed by the pretty sights, go in space battles or combat in fps style. You may also salvage data sticks and other supplies. The data sticks are these little bits of the story and surprisingly funny. That's about it, not much, but there may be much more according to raptor (The dev)

In terms of bugs there aren't many due to the lack of content, as the game is currently a frame for what's to come. But there is a surprising amount of freedom in customization of your vessel (interior only),
and that freedom will only improve as I see.

Space combat is surprisingly good, much better then others as the fire mechanic can lead to some pretty intense battles with multiple craft, really makes you have to use some maneuvers to avoid missiles and blasters, but even this can get repetitive at times.

Another big aspect of the game is customizing your ship, many of my hours in the game have been customizing trying new layouts as there is simply so much you can do and it'll only get better with time.

Another plus the game gets is the lack of loading screens, as this is much better for people who love immersion in their games. There isn t even a loading screen on new game. Speaking of which, The beginning of the game is pretty simple, you spawn on  an asteroid near your ship, after a basic tutorial you get in and from there salvage and fight. That's basically the whole game for now.

[h1] STORY [/h1]
     Believe it or not the story for this game is very interesting and original (compared to the other space games) and the game currently tells the story through data sticks you find, the story from what I put together goes as: Humanity has grown tired and used up earth, now boarding a massive scale ship, called the Rodina is heading towards a star system called the Zorica system, housing 4 planets and an asteroid belt, now your character who by default is named Sara was aboard a space craft sent to colonize the system, prior to the Rodina.

The Zorica system was infested with aliens who destroyed the vanguard and your the only know survivor, your only goal right now is kill as many aliens, possibly wiping them our or driving them out so they don't destroy all of humanity when the Rodina arrives.

So the story is very original and the story telling as well is fun!

[h1] GRAPHICS [/h1]
     The graphics in Rodina have a cute little pixels in them and a nice charm to them, specifically the fire extinguisher affects after putting out a fire. I'm sure there will be many improvements and changes. Its very easy to run and you should be fine running it.

[h1] AUDIO [/h1]
     The sounds in the game are cute and fun, while the music is simply spectacular, If you want to help Raptor make this game then go ahead and buy the soundtrack as it has a very ominous and star trek feel to it, winning me over instantly.

[h1] OVERALL [/h1]
     Overall Rodina in its current state, can be fun at times but might not be a game you'll play all day, not yet already as it's currently lacking in content but that's soon to change and I have great faith in Raptor for making this good game and if you want to support it too, go buy it as the price range is fair for its current state as well.

[h1] 6/10 [/h1] A good game that's above average at the moment, I'm sure that will change for the better.

32054231.review:
Damn good game with a hell of a lot of potential. The dev posts updates regularly and is active in communicating where the game is going, so this is one piece of early access that I have no worries about becoming abandonware.

The story, while complete as far as major plot elements, is still unfinished. Mind you, the story itself is entirely text based, but it's damn well written. They did a great job of keeping me both guessing and wanting more. I found myself trying to bolt from place to place to find out how everything would progress.

Exploration is definitely this game's strongest point. The planets are HUGE and there's plenty to poke around with in the asteroid belt. There are some elements that haven't been finished yet, but that you can find floating in orbit within the system. To say that I'm curious to see how they're going to be implimented would be an understatement.

Some elements do feel somewhat grind-y. The big one being ground combat with collecting items. I like curve-balls thrown my way with games like this, so take what I say next as you will. When landing to collect items, there's always a handful of ground troops to deal with. While that's not a bad thing, there's not really much variation with it. (Especially with the variety and number of enemies you come up against.) Sure, you could land, get out of your ship, and engage them that way, but over time I found myself just hovering above them in my starship lighting them up with the ship's main guns. The situation felt a little... Overpowered. (Though there was one instance where a ground troop had some sort of rocket launcher energy weapon that wrecked my shizzle. Pleasant surprise and I appreciated having to mix up my strategy.) I have nothing wrong with a situation like that, but being able to rinse-later-repeat that scenario over and over again feels like a bit of a balancing issue to me. If they added some element that necessitated me getting out of my ship to attack the enemy, that would help mix things up a bit. Maybe add something like SAM/AA batteries (Both stationary and mobile) that can fire at you while in the ship, but not on the ground. Another idea would be to have the enemy send out something like a distress call to nearby patrolling aircraft if you're attacking the ground forces with your ship rather than on foot. There are some aircraft patrols, but they're not very regular. The potential is definitely there, but there's certainly room for improvement.

Aircraft battles, by comparison, are significantly more difficult and far more satisfying when you win. (Ground battles are definitely lacking in the satisfaction/accomplishment department even when you're fighting from the ground.) Strangely, the battleships are fairly easy to take out with a hit and run tactic, while bombers with fighter escorts are way harder to deal with. (Enjoyably so too.)

Overall, this game is definitely worth the price. (I have yet to run into any noticeable bugs. The whole thing runs really smooth.) It's immensely enjoyable. Normally I try to stay away from early access, but this one is truly a gem. Awesome as it is in its current state, I'm definitely looking forward to future updates.

31583336.review:
This game is phenomenal.  Absolutely fantastic!  It's built in an old-school style, with no loading screens, no waypoints, no tutorials, no dumbed down guidance.  It gives (nearly) absolute freedom to go whereever you want, do whatever you want (aside from a minor planet-locking system, which is not grindy and well-done IMHO).  The game plays completely in first person, or allows you to move about in your ship first person and fly third person (I personally prefer all first-person play).  You literally press a button, while flying, and can walk about your ship as you fly, totally seamless.  You can open your airlock (while in space) and get sucked out as the interior atmosphere escapes into space, you can jump out of your ship while planetside and drop to the planet.  Atmospheric re-entry is extremly cool, and gives you the feeling that you are in a real spaceship being tossed, turned, and burned as you plunge.

Gameplay mechanics perfectly follow the KISS (keep it simple stupid) principle, there are debris fields all over the asteroid belt and the four planets, which are inhabited by Xenos (hostile aliens) who attack you from various ships, and also on the ground in a sort of "Tribes" like FPS combat.  As you gather debris and encryption keys from the debris fields, more of the story unlocks (all text based).  Don't be dissuaded by the text based story, it is extremely well written and pulls you into the game like a good book, and has a fantastic twist.

Probably the very best aspect is the musical soundtrack.  It flawlessly captures the feeling of lonesome space sickness, the awe of extra-solar planetary exploration, and changes thematically depending upon your position, with each planet and area getting it's own theme.  The music is in an orchestral style, and holds it's own against the likes of John Williams (Star Wars).

Can't wait to see where this developer takes Rodina next.  Speaking as an older old-school gamer, this game is absolutely the best thing to happen to space games since LucasFilms in the late eighties.

All that said, if you are a multiplayer fan (I am not), I don't know that this would be the title for you, as I don't believe the developer has worked on netcode or has any plans to incorporate it (fairly certain here).  Also, there is no voice acting, and no top-of the line animations, though what is there (animation wise) is extremely smooth and aesthetically pleasing in it's own right.  Also, while the planets and planetside landings are extremely cool, and the seamless nature of the game makes them fun to explore, they are rather barren, and could use quite a bit of love.

Can't recommend this one enough, it stands with the best classics.

I tend to rate games on whether they provide at least 1 hour of entertainment per £. Well, given that I just reached that point, I can say that this game does.

Be warned, though, it is NOT a complete game. It's the bare-bones of a game. It's playable, it's fun and it's a great teaser of what might come next, but if you're looking for a fully polished space game, this isn't it. Go and get Elite or something.

Basically, you're a person who is flying round, building their ship up, killing aliens and following some vague plot threads about the state of humanity and the events preceeding the game. These threads begin to draw together and form what the game calls 'Chapter One', which I found very enticing, and which goes in a very interesting direction by the end. Presumably, I'm on Chapter Two now, which involves building a wang for a robot, but again, this is dressed in a very interesting set of threads.

One of the main features that this game has over most is the ship interior editor and moddability. Say you want to have the Enterprise, you can make your interior like it, then download a model to make it look like that (I'm not actually sure if there is an Enterprise, the mod scene is small). Or if you want a little ship, you could have one room with all the stuff you need. Even though the building system is very much not complete, it's still really fun and quite powerful (and multiple levels and a better layout planner are on the cards for the future updates).

All in all, if you're willing to take a punt, buy it or try the demo. If you want to hold off, you do that and wait until it's got more features. Hopefully, there will be some major updates in 2017, which looking at the dev's monthly-ish track record, looks likely.

Every place you visit seems like a new challenging experience from the landing of the aircraft to the looting of new items. Some things that could be tweaked though:

- Lack of personality/character. I think introducing some type of AI with the ship such as a HAL could make the game go a long way.

- More diversity in looting areas. Everywhere you land your ship to get items its the same thing with aliens shooting you, why not some places with just items or even friendly AI? 

- Video data fragments. I think the implention of Video data fragments into the game for cutscenes would be another great way to build onto the story. After a lot of data collecting going back and reading tons of paragraphs can lose interest.

- More places to visit, not necessarily planets, but checkpoints inbetween such as moons, galaxies, etc. This doesn't have to be story related it could even be for more items drops or just scenery.

This review consists of the factors that led me to the decision of buying this game. I originally started off with the demo, and I was sold. I insist you do the same.

The story and soundtrack in Rodina are supurb. Although the main story in this game isn't on par with games like Mass Effect, for a one man dev, the writing is fantastic (I'm not sure if Brendan/Raptormeat does all the writing or if he has help). Rodina's story is refreshing, in a sense that you really feel like the transmissions you read are from real people in a real universe. I've been on the edge of my seat when reading some of these. The story drew me into this ficitonal universe.

The soundtrack, story, ship customization, and the sheer scale of the planets are what really drew me in. I'm a gamer that loves a good soundtrack, and this game definitely delivers.

At the time of writing, I have 9 hours logged (I bought this game yesterday (1/16)); and I would say that 4 of those hours were consumed by ship customization. You have complete freedom when customizing your ship. There are mods for this game that one can download to acquire new types of ships, but I really enjoy the simplicity of the vanilla ship.

As for the planets, there has been countless times where I've landed my ship, thinking I was close to my target, when in reality, I was hundred of meters off. People who have played this game know what I'm talking about. At times, it's truley hard to comprehend how massive some of these planets really are.

If you're not yet convinced, try the demo. With the demo, you acquire the entire game, but are limted to 90 minutes of gameplay. If you decide to buy the game, you can start right where you left off. 

So start with the demo, and enjoy a truly remarkable game.

29153940.review:
I've had a few hours to explore, get comfy with the controls (very easy to learn) and shoot down a few bad guys in space and on the ground. How best to describe this flawed gem? I'm Smitten is how!

Daggerfall in Space is the term the dev wants us to recognise this as and at this stage i can see it coming together. Planets in this alpha are all pretty much barren wastelands but with the introduction of ground/outdoor combat they have enemy NPC's guaring supply drops and there's even some ships to fight flying in the skies of the planet, not just in space.

Space combat feels great. The bullets are sparatic and spread out really far but you can deal some serious damage from a good distance. Enemy fighters will try to get behind you while larger ships tend to deploy homing missiles and fire some slow moving torpedos that hardly hit you but hurt when they do.

Ground combat with the two blasters you can use is farely basic, nothing special, but it's fun. You have your default blaster that shoots as fast as you can click with a hold-down attack or the repeat blaster which shoots continuously when held down.

The exploration is fun. The portential is staggering! It's empty of anything friendly and the game is incredibly lonely but with plans for cities and friendly NPC's on planets along with multiplayer I have high hopes that this game will only get better.

Best of all, this space sim has made no false promises.

Pros:
-Space Combat is fun
-Huge solar system, mind bogglingly realistic, with plenty to explore
-Jumping on asteroids (weeeeeee)
-The ship interiors make me smile, so homely
-Can bombard enemy troops on the ground with my ship guns!
-Great Music
-Seamless planet transistion with a very realistic atmospheric entry 

Cons:
-Graphics are a weak point but easily looked past
-Ground combat is still new and bare bones but fun though I see it becoming a chore
-Some lackluster sound effects
-Lonely game :(

I hope this one keeps it's promises!

28649393.review:
Dissapointed by No Man's Sky and need something to scratch your space exploration itch? Rodina might be the game for you.

In Rodina you explore a vast solar system with 4 massive planets all roughly the size earth and tens of thousands of asteroids. You will need to scavenge items and fight off hostile xenos to uncover the storyline. The feeling of loneliness surrounds you and the amazing soundtrack enchances the feeling of solitude.

The storyline is absolutely amazing even when it's purely made of text. Be prepared to read. It will keep you engaged and it will surprise you.

The combat happens in air and on land. The land battles FPS battles against xenos with different kind of weaponry. The air/space battles are fought with space ships and different kind of weaponry which you can easily equip to your spaceship. My only problem with the combat is that the guns you get to currently use in land combat feel like peashooters, so it's a lot easier to just kill everyone with your spaceship.

The spaceship has a fully customisable interior, which I have spent a lot of time on making it fit me. It really adds to the homeliness of the spaceship. While the exterior can't be changed in the current version in vanilla, modding the game is pretty easy so you can go download exteriors for Nexus Mods. So with mods you can fully customize the ship to your liking.

There is basically only one type of thing you do to get forward in the game. Fly into a plus sign in an object, kill all enemies on the site, and salvage the items left there. It might sound lame but I have had a lot of fun with it so far, purely because the atmosphere engrosses me in the world.

This game is still in early access, but it still manages to do what many other games will never achieve. Best part is... It keeps getting updated and in the coming year the game will advance a lot. I recommend looking the roadmap at the Elliptic Games site.

Basically this game is worth your money in it's current state and it will only get better from now. Buy it.

28500023.review:
Finish your damn game.  It's been two years now.

UPDATE:

My review is fair and accurate.  This game has been in early access with very limited progress for over two years now.  If you can't devote the time and energy necessary to finish the project, then don't charge money for it.

Steam is littered with games such as Drifter and Jumpdrive that are stuck in perpetual early access hell with infrequent or nonexistent updates while remaining borderline unplayable proofs of concept.  And much like those games, Rodina has an interesting concept and has potential to be a good game.

However, it is not a good game, it is not moving at any appreciable pace toward becoming a good game, and the purpose of reviewing a game is to offer an honest assessment of said game.  A reviewi s not a hopeful prediction of what the game will be in five years if the developer actually decides to work on his game.

Those who recommend a game based on the theoretical potential of the game are no better than the yahoos at PC Gamer who gave Outpost one of their highest scores ever and it turned out to be a worthless tech demo with no actual gameplay.  Remember that?  I do.

Cheers.

28282096.review:
Rodina, for having a story that plays out entirely by text, has one of the best stories I've read/played/experienced in a long time. The story combined with the stunning star system the game takes place in really make Rodina a great experience despite not being so early in it's development. The updates to the stable branch are few and far between but when they come out you can always tell how much the developer cares about the game he's creating. Truly a gem in the Early Access scene.

As far as the game itself goes, the combat is challenging and fun, it doesn't feel at all boring or cookie cutter. The music is probably some of the best I've heard out of a small indie title like this, and the planets are properly massive and breath taking. The models are for the most part very primitive, yes, but you'll hardly notice that as you're trying to put out fires and shoot down enemy ships.

I could probably go on for a while longer about all the things I love about this game, but my favorite thing by far are the organic movie-esque scenes that happen on a regular basis. Watching enemy ships fall to the planet below in a ball of flame is probably one of my favorite things in the world.

28134481.review:
What is more frightening than a God?

This question was posed to me upon completing Rodina's main story, as well as the answer, in quick succession.  Not literally, of course, but thematically; I felt that this was the underlying thesis of the entire work.  My interpretation, anyway.

That's probably a pretentious way to start.  Okay!  I'll talk about the game now in more literal terms.

Short version:

Do I recommend?  That depends.  Rodina is quickly becoming one of my favorite games, but that's because it's both a fun  activity that revolves around interesting exploration in a vast, vast world and a vehicle for philosophical quandaring through some pretty excellent writing.  If this does not appeal to you, then no, I don't recommend.  If it sounds remotely intriguing, then yes, I whole-heartedly recommend.  Do it.  Play the demo.  Then pay the 250 that this company sorely deserves (if I had that on hand I would do so in a heart-beat).

Long version:

I'll describe the game by listing and explaining each facet any game would typically have.

Graphics: 

Subpar.  I find the visuals to be charming, reminding me of a few games I used to play when I was a kid fiddling around with my parents' bulky Macintosh.  Honestly I never cared about the graphical style of a game I'm playing, so long as it doesn't hamper the overall experience (I like Minecraft, for example).  Compared to some AAA games out there, it'd get trampled in this department.  However, I think the initially unappealing look of the game works to the game's advantage, in what I think the game attempts to portray.  I won't spoil, however.

(I saw that there was a separate artist for this game, so don't take this as me dissing you - I'm only comparing it to games that have like a zillion dollars backing it and pretty much nothing else, and also I can barely draw a stick figure so take that what its worth.)

Gameplay:

The actual, full-on, no BS reason I bought this game in the first place was because I read you can walk around in your own ship.  Seriously.  After playing Starbound and finding great satisfaction in essentially piloting a flying house, not being tethered to anything anywhere else, I was greeted with a great sense of freedom I don't find in any other game.  Alas, Starbound was still limited (2D notwithstanding), and I longed for even greater freedom.  Rodina, then, heard my call, burst into my living room, stripped itself of all clothing articles, and demanded that I make love with it.  Of course with the graphics I was mostly aversive but I at least complimented its hair.

Okay, okay.  So yes.  Walking around in your own ship - a ship whose interior you can design AND walk around in whilst mid-flight - was just really fun for me.  As was the difficult control scheme.  Learning to fly took a lot of effort, but it made it worth it.  Same with dog-fighting.  I've seen complaints for this, but honestly, I found the hectic nature of the space battles riveting.  Especially when you're in the atmosphere of a planet, having to pay attention to where you are so you don't burn up while also keeping track of the swarm of enemies trying to practice their anti-protagonist agenda.

In addition to movement and such, I am also continuously amazed at the size of this world.  It's merely a solar system, yes, but holy cow is it gigantic.  The planets feel collosal, in a way that makes you quickly realize that you're just a speck.  Likewise with the distance between planets and asteroids.  There's just a scope here that I'm still wrapping my head around.  If nothing else, this game seriously hammers in the idea that, hey, space is really big.  Like, bigger than the biggest thing you can think of.  Yes, THAT big.  Some kind of space scientist would be proud.

If I had one minor complaint, though, it's that I think the Xenos' weapons are a bit over-powered.  Not against your character, mind - that's just fine.  I expect a rocket to blow your face off.  However, how come a few pew pew bullets can down your entire space-craft?  Especially those homing thingies.  Two of those and you're gone.  Feels kind of uneven to me, but what do I know?

Story:

And this is where we rub up on the reason I think this game works as well as it does.  I'll get this out of the way, first, though - the writing is excellent.  Delegated to out-of-the-way documents that you can collect, each contain a small part of a short story that interconnects with the greater context of the universe.  It is not required that you read any of them in order to get any enjoyment out of the game, but doing so will deepen the world you inhabit while you murder those poor green men.

That is, until you rip through the story without reading anything and get to the end, where you should be thoroughly confused by what happens.  And this is where I fell in love with the game.

It's not visibly enormous or spectacular by any means, no.  It'd just generate a small bit of confusion that may compel you to read why it happened.  But for me, this created a thrust that I just haven't seen anywhere else.  A context was created that perfectly married the graphics, game, and story into a single entity - you.  The player.  A trajectory is set at that moment, one that I'm unsure could be stopped, and I think the understanding of that is what propels this game into the profound.  In the end, it made me realize that with the scope of the game's world, the abilities I possessed, and the enemies I've mowed down, I realized what exactly this protagonist was capable of now, and will be capable of in the future.

The game at this point asks, what is more frightening than a God?  And you get the answer to that as quick as the question is asked.  And this, Mr. Ebert, is why you're wrong - this video game IS art, and it's art in a way that no other form of media would be able to accomplish.  Or I could just be talking out of my ass like some pretentious hipster.

Anyway, to all those involved in this wonderful work's creation, thank you.

Rodina is a space exploration based early acces game that just might suprise you.

You start simple, with picking up ship upgrades, ammo and data sticks from asteroids.

- a large generated universe
- 4 massive planets to explore
- 45.000 asteroids to discover
- exploration rewards you with better ammo and upgrades
- space and fps combat

- the game is well written

- the ONLY thing that you can customize is your ship layout
- on some systems this game is prone to crashing

27550787.review:
Rodina. What a beautiful game, I simply can't understand why you would play anything else.

First of all this game is set in space so it's already cool, but what is even better is your FULLY CUSTOMISABLE SPACESHIP! with that you can really get to know your ship and maybe even roleplay a bit.

Then there are space enemies, meaning you can have epic space battles fighting with or against a variety of weapons. Or you could decide to take it to close combat and blast the alien fools once you've boarded their space stations.

Meanwhile in this already fully immersive and incredible combat you will have some cool music playing. Music, no big deal right? Wrong. The music in this game makes it twice as better even if you're cruising around a planet, or in fast paced combat or even running around your spaceship like a madman.

After all this there is more! The flying in this game is absolutely brilliant, at all times you feel very in control of what your ship is doing. (Except when you are in limnal drive.) Zoom around space at multiple speeds and really understand how BIG space is. Even at the fastest speed you're going to have trouble reaching the other end.

The Planets are excellent and many aliens inhabit them. Then there are hundreds of asteroids, seriously that isnt an exageration. The asteroids also inhabited by aliens. Then as mentioned before there are alien space stations littered around space. On all planets and asteroids there is tons of loot to find including space emails that progresses the story. All planets have there own music too!

The very simple art style works perfectly.

This has been my review on Rodina, obviously this game is in early access at the moment and things could change but when it is finished i will look forward to playing it. At it's current state i would give it a very honest 9.5/10.

-Niteguard

I never write reviews because I'm lazy, but this one deserves it. This is basically what you need to know:


- Music is ON POINT! Truly awesome.

- Right now the story is somewhat short, but really interesting.

- Controls are simple, yet allow for complex maneuvers. You get full six-degrees-of-freedom, along with real physics-based motion.

- The gameplay is super immersive. The transitions between battling in space, landing on a planet, or walking about your moving ship are completely seamless.

- There is nothing really stopping you from doing anything. Yes, it is possible to open the airlock as your ship burns up in atmospheric entry, and get sucked out into space... and then you're stuck there with a tiny jetpack. It's fun.

- Music is just amazing.

- Had plenty of "oh snap, I didn't know this was a thing" moments for me.

- The developer seems to have a realistic timeline, and doesn't promise anything that can't be delivered. The game gets wholesome updates on a regular basis. Check out the site to see what is planned (or don't and be surprised).

25860354.review:
There are pretty games.

Then there are [i]really[/i] pretty games.

Then there is rodina.

*ahem* Allow me to correct myself.

Then there is motherfucking Rodina. 

over my 22 hours on this game, I experienced something... atmospheric. it's something of a throwaway term in most games, but in rodina, I found something that made my hair stand on end and my spine tingle at the sublime, raw scale, a feeling which I can only describe as atmospheric.

---POETRY MODE DISABLED---

Rodina is genuinely one of the most interesting concepts to come out of the shitpile that can be early access in recent years- a game that, even though the game contains less content than some walking simulators, it still managed to hold my attention for long periods of time. mostly this was the subtly told and well thought out backstory that kept me really interested and hunting for more, mostly revealed through a series of logs, books and decrypted conversations. but the sheer size and grandeur of this seemingly extremely humble game is really something to behold- if it can retain that, while also becoming a legitimate finished game, it will be one of the best science fiction games I've ever played.

I paid 10 pounds for this. honestly, even for the current product, I'd pay 15. 

[i]It's just that pretty.[i/]

25396881.review:
its a basic-graphics space opera with you as a lone survivor of some spaceship accident.  Your ship is fully playable 3d, and you can get out of the airlock at any time to wander around planets (asteroids first).  you bumble about piecing together the story and upgrading your ship with wreckage until you can do FTL and explore the rest of the system, but be warned - ALIENS!

at the moment im no match for more than a small patrol of aliens, and the first planet i came across was swarming with orbital navy. i guess i'd better go exploring some more and gear my ship up!

its really quite a good game, with a nice into to the controls and story.  the graphics are purposely minimal but the music is really cool. i particularly like the "gear shift" system for controlling engine speed, allowing you fine control when near objects and planets, and sooper speed when in clear space.    

the grind up to ftl and exploring the system isnt too steep, which was nice. the ship appears to have some complex controls dotted around it (you can for example, emergency-vent the ship of atmosphere. protip here tho - don't do it out of curiosity, you get blown out of the airlock also)   there are various guns hanging on the wall around the ship so i assume i'm going to meet some of these aliens face to face sooner or later. 

this is a really nice little game, and i look forward to more versions in future. it's already worthy of the low price for exploration and fun's sake. it's doing some really technically difficult stuff with the variances in distance and scale, and it seems like a really slick piece of software.

I love this game.

It is quite minimalistic at the moment but it reminds me of the days playing Elite Frontier.

The storyline/discovered documents are very well written and the game is functionally solid.  I really hope that the developer continues to expand the game.

Although "early access" it is well worth the money.  It's a bit like when Kerbal Space Program was "early access" - you already have a full game if you buy it right now - but there is the promise of more to come.

Even if development stopped at this point, I think the game is worth the price.  If you see it on special offer then there is NO reason not to purchase it.  If you like space exploration games, you will like Rodina.

For all its minimalism, it still manages to create its own "atmosphere" and "feel".

I don't own No Man's Sky.  I was going to get it, but after everything I have read, Rodina seems like it does a better job and it costs a quarter of the price and it is still under development.  I will stick with Rodina.

25236846.review:
I am a big fan of space simulators, open world and sandbox genre. KSP was fun, but I played much more hardcore OrbiterSim for countless hours. One boring evening I was scrolling past my discovery queue when Rodina showed up. I watched the video and was like "errr... ok, let's see how childish/failed this is". So I downloaded the demo aaaand...
...I regained consciousness right before sunrise in real world, having bought the full version and played it for hours like an addict!
Consider this: Rodina can not yet impress you with outstanding visuals, rich/variable content and even diversity of in-game activities.
Consider also this: the most fascinating part of Rodina gameplay is its [b]storyline[/b]!
Finally, consider this: the main drama happens lightyears away from you, you do not know any of the characters involved nor can you influence their decisions in any way besides following the very straightforward and scripted plot line, you don't even talk to anyone, you just receive regular updates on what other characters say and do for your sake or demise.
And yet it is the excellent storytelling that makes Rodina outstanding for me. I was jumping the locations in genuine eagerness and anticipation of the next plot twist and overall had much much fun. When it was finally over, I felt sad much like when a fascinating book ends.

Now I'd like to comment on some technicalities. This game is developed by one person. So you don't complain about locations design, more than necessary arcade-ish physics, lack of any orbital/entry mechanics whatsoever, stupidity and lack of initiative in your adversaries -- you can even easily finish the whole story without firing a single shot, dubious lighting, visible LOD switching and basically everything that procedural generation entails. It is not about that at all.

If you have a vivid imagination, I strongly recommend playing Rodina.

25024097.review:
Rodina is No Man's Sky with heart. 

At is core, Rodina is a space-faring scavenger hunt. Although there is plenty of space fighter combat - and the AI pilots display impressive teamwork - these sequences are merely obstacles to the core of Rodina: Scouring the solar system for apocalyptic logs that tell the story of the original Rodina mission. It's clear that the developer (one person, I believe) puts most of the focus on collecting the log fragments and encrypted messages that unveil the fascinating retrospective exposition. If you enjoy reading the messages and log entries scattered throughout games like System Shock 2, Deus Ex, and Bioshock, you will find much to enjoy here.

It's equally clear that combat and logistics have been super-simplified in order to prevent player frustration and to keep the focus on exploring and searching. All action takes place within a single solar system. Logistics are utterly simple: Ship and personnel damage are repaired automatically, most weapons can be fired constantly without reloading, and engine upgrades speed travel from point to point. Your ship's floor plan can be customized from the airlock menu, but this seems like a placeholder feature with no practical impact. Similarly, if a fire breaks out on your ship, you must exit the cockpit and race around the ship's deck spraying a fire extinguisher at the flames. This adds to the tension of an already dangerous battle or planetfall, but it also comes across as a placeholder with zero narrative or gameplay purpose.

If Rodina truly is completely the work of a single person, that person is both a skilled software developer and a talented author of fiction. Be warned, though: If you buy Rodina as a space combat simulator in the vein of Descent: Freespace or Wing Commander, or if you don't like to read, you will be disappointed.

Special praise for the soundtrack, which sets the mood perfectly even during combat.

25007591.review:
TLDR: Rodina is a decent game that is worth picking up especially if, after trying the demo, you want to support ongoing development. However, too much emphasis is placed on the ship interior editor. 6.5/10

[b]Pros:[/b]

[list]
[*]Truly seamless travel through a large solar system

[*]Somewhat realistic flight physics

[*]In-game sandbox in the form of ship interior customization, if that's your thing

[*]Evocative, haunting soundtrack

[*]Well written story, in the form of decrypted messages and miscellaneous context

[*]Two story-less modes, i.e., with and without enemy ships. Moar sandbox!
[/list]

[b]Cons:[/b]

[list]
[*]Planets are all barren wastelands

[*]Combat mechanics are too simple, and yet combat is very difficult and rather unsatisfying in any case

[*]Repetitive story mode gameplay: descend to planet, acquire relevant data, repeat
[/list]

This game is clearly a love letter from the lone developer to space exploration afficionados. The developer remains active and committed to furthering the game, and is transparent about what's in the pipe. So, though it may lack in content and gameplay at the time of this review, it will only get better.

24946262.review:
25 November 2017 - This game is still receiving updates and is still engaging.

TL;DR - Recommended.  If you aren't sure, then play the free demo.
Unfinished, but still easily worth the price.  Aspires to be Daggerfall in space.  Already immersive.  Fun flight gameplay, Unreal/Quake style FPS gameplay.

Because I don't want to forget, I'll mention this up front: the music's great.  There aren't many tunes, but they're all very evocative of whatever environment or situation triggers them.

You can edit the layout of your ship; the current assets are simple, but still enough to keep you busy personalizing it.  The exterior shape is static regardless of how you arrange the interior, but the interior is still a physical place that you walk through to get to the cockpit.

Piloting the ship actually gives the feeling of navigating a massive, largely empty space.  You've got four "gears" depending on how far you want to go and how fast you want to get there.  The ship manages to feel ponderous at some speeds and agile at others.

The exploration involves flying your ship to a celestial body of indeterminate size, landing your ship, and then getting out of your ship and grabbing the loot.  There are text logs that provide information on the culture and context of the game, ammo pickups for your ship, and upgrades to let you visit specific places.  The planets are bare, but terrain is quite varied.  Counterintuitively, the closer you get, the less detail you see.

Dogfighting has been implemented - quite well, I think - but there doesn't seem to be any progression, so the enemies are exactly as tough several hours in as they were at the beginning.  You have your infinite-ammo chaingun, but you can also pick up ammunition for special weapons.
I've seen three types of enemy ship in space (scout, bomber, battleship) and an additional one in atmosphere.

The FPS combat takes place in procedurally-generated pieces of debris.  For me, the easiest point of reference is Nethack.  Rooms of random size connecting to other rooms of random size, although thankfully Rodina lacks the dead-end tunnels.
There's only one weapon at the moment, a Megaman-style blaster, and only one type of enemy with the same weapon.  However, being from the old school of FPS gameplay, the combat tends to be frenetic and challenging rather than dull.  Lots of strafing and either rapid clicking or twitchy charged shots.

24678004.review:
Been tooling around with this game for a while now and am getting excited about a few of the recent updates. You're now able to explore an open world solar system, travel on foot/jetpack or your customizable spacecraft, shoot baddies with your blaster pistol or spacecraft weapons, and search for shards of the games narrative and other loot on distant planets and asteroids.

To be sure, the current world is severly underpopulated, both in terms of NPC characters and interesting things to do, but it makes me feel immersed in a big and authentic spaceworld that includes planets, and that's totally awesome. Another big selling point for me is the ability to enter the atmosphere of a planet and land on its surface without ever staring at a loading screen. In fact, intering atmo is one of the few parts of the game that actually has game-mechanics currently, which is a big plus.

The score was exactly what I wanted it to be: big and sweeping and pretty much lifted from my favorite sci-fi movies. Each planet gets its own track, though there isn't much else to do while you listen but fly around and watch the pretty day/night cycles while fending off the occasional bogey. Eh, who am I kidding, I'm down for that. It gives me the "first-time-playing-Minecraft chills," if you know what I mean.

Dev work is slow and methodical, but they're keeping their promises so far, and that's good.

Definitely worth the investment for me, but that's just what it is right now, an "investment." It's not a full game by any means, but definitely promising from my perspective.

I've longed for a space/planet exploration game for years, and this scratches that itch in a really awesome way. The sense of scale is unparalled - from jumping from asteroid to asteroid to descending into the atmosphere of a full-sized planet for the first time, it's easy to get lost in Rodina.

The story is short, but well-written and engaging. I can watch a beautiful (albeit lonely) sunset from an icy mountain on the farthest planet, then jump back in my ship go blasting aliens a few seconds later.

It's made by a single developer, who (after 2 years) still manages to put out updates.

24609548.review: Rodina is a fantastic game that I was lucky enough to find while browsing through Steam. It has everything that I want in a space exploration game and although it is still a work in progress, it shows signs of improving vastly with each new update. So if you are wondering what Rodina offers, it's basically this: You start on an asteroid where you find your ship. After you board your ship, the galaxy opens up to you. It's not a whole universe, but it is the largest game map I've ever seen. An entire galaxy is ready to be explored and it feels massive in scale. For instance, when you look in the sky, you see hundreds of dots which are each collections of smaller asteroids. The asteroids can be explored, and often contain loot. However the biggest appeal is planets, which are massive in scale. It would take hours to fly around one and probably days to walk, as compared to the thousands of asteroids which don't take very long to completely explore (Keep in mind this is real life time, not in game time). Once you've taken in the awe of the scale of it all, you can explore the galaxy to unravel the game's story. As of writing this, there are no npc's, but the story comes in the form of written documents scattered on planets and asteroids. It's very well written and it's easy to get lost in the lore and backstory of it all. I won't spoil anything but it's worth playing for. Combat is also really fun. There are several types of enemies and weapons you can use to fight them. It feels like space battles done right and it's all very enoyable. The other thing you can do in this game is customize your ship. There is a well designed customizing feature that is very easy to use and lets you make your ship unique. There is also another feature the game added which is awesome, but may be a minor spoiler so only scroll over this part if you want to know: [spoiler]Once you beat the story you have the ability to make robots. They don't have dialoge but they follow you around and are pretty neat.[/spoiler] However, this brings me to Rodina's biggest flaw (flaw is a strong word but I can't think of a better one): It's very empty. The loneliness of space can bother some people and I can understand if some people get bored or disinterested. I should make something clear: this game is in early access, so if you want to get this game be aware that it is empty in terms of content and the gameplay can be boring and/or lacking at times. If you are like me and roleplay in your head you won't get too bored, but if you prefer your story more straightfoward then you may not have as much fun as other people playing this game. So should you get this game? Yes. If you are not sure there is a free demo on the store page. It's the full game with a 1 hr. time limit and should give you a great idea of what you are in for. However after replaying the hour of the demo I think everyone should buy this game at full price. The price is very reasonable for what you are getting, it's very fun, and it runs great on low end pc's like mine (as of writing this.) If you are a fan of space exploration then I absolutely recommend this game.

24467707.review:
Rodina is fantastic. Intuitive controls (which you can re-map as you choose), quality worldbuilding done through without a single voice actor, and unbelievably immersive storytelling. Not to mention beautiful procedural generation.

And yes, the game isn't fully fleshed out quest-wise, but I've always been one to enjoy a game where I can just *be*. Few games allow you to really feel like an explorer, and this is one of them. Nothing is more relaxing to me than grabbing a load of items from a frosty crevasse on Morena and immediately, seamlessly flying out of the atmosphere and throttling down to zero to admire the beautiful galaxy spread before you. Sometimes I touch down on Jarilo just to sit and watch the sunset. I've only ever experienced really beautiful moments like that in a few games, notably Elder Scrolls, but this certainly far exceeds my expectations.

Rodina also has the best dev I've ever seen. Seriously, the Rodina subreddit is full of comments from random users who have their concerns addressed and/or patched within hours by the "team" of one guy who must work insanely hard on this project of his. I'm proud to have funded the development of this game, because not only is it a 10/10 space sim in its own right, I know the development will continue indefinitely. I absolutely recommend this game.

Rodina is a fun game if you take it in moderate doses. I've spent too many hours perfecting the interior design of my starship. There's just something so satisfying about creating the layout of your own ship and then flying anywhere in the solar system, seamlessly. The controls feel slick and taking off from a stand still right into light speed never gets old. The writing and story is pretty good. The graphics are gorgeous if you're into minamalist retro. And the soundtrack! Oh amazing. It really sets a star warsy atmosphere.
But like I said this game is only enjoyable if you don't take it too seriously. The combat is flawed and needs balancing. I find myself enganging in combat for maybe thirty seconds before I have to retreat and wait a good minute for my health to replenish, then having to repeat this maybe three or four times before I can beat the baddies. It gets frustrating. The story is pretty easy to complete if you're in a rush. More variety in enemies would be nice.
All in all though it's a pretty good game and has potential to be better.

I bought the game to support indie developing, but there wasn't for me more than 40-50 minutes of gameplay before I got tired of landing on a planet, picking up the bits and pieces on the surface, and taking off.  Repeat x5 and I was getting a little bored.  The gameplay is interesting, but repetitive.  An autopilot to selected planet would help, as would an auto-land feature.  The "no loading" feature is amazing, as the game more or less seamlessly transitions from deep space to planetary atmosphere.  Atmospheric landing was interesting; I loved the shaking of the spacecraft during atmospheric descent.  The game leaves you quite on your own at the beginning, and some tips in the tutorial would be welcome.  (Hint: follow all indicators on your screen, and land as close to them as possible.)  I will probably leave the game for a few weeks and revisit, just to give myself a fresh chance at it.  Overall, not recommended from me at this time, but the game has real potential and needs to flesh out the universe for it really to come into its own. 

2017-02: back to playing with it and I am reminded that the music is fantastic. I bought the soundtrack to support the developer.  Finding the alien NPCs to be a bit comedic as they race at full tilt around asteroid surfaces shooting blasters at you.  I'm sure this will be fleshed out in future versions.  Still find the game slightly tedious and the planet surfaces boring, but I'll make my way to one of the new gravity bikes and try those out, if I can.  All gripes aside, floating in space listening to the excellent music is worth a few bucks.  Graphics are nothing to write home about, but somehow, it's easy to overlook them while you float in space.  I'd recommend at a discounted price, or for anyone who just loves to tool around in a free world-universe (that doesn't really have that much going on) while listening to great music.  Will continue to explore.

I bought the game at 1am after I finished work and played until 8am in one sitting.

It had an incredibly engaging, indepth, gripping, thought-provoking story.

At first I was just flying around and experiencing the mechanics of the game, which I love.
The flight is much simpler and streamlined than other space simulators, with an easy to understand interface.
No loading screens means 100% immersion that never breaks.
If this game had VR support it would take the cake.
The way you unlock mechanics through in game events is very fluid.
You can also customise the interior of your ship with a fairly powerful editor.

Then, while usually I read slowly I started reading the logs I was picking up and became enthralled in the story.
Instead of flying around to fly around. It was fly around to learn what happens next. 

I won't spoil it for you because it was one of the best experiences I've had in a while, better than watching a good movie.


Exquisitely crafted and I will be watching this game for updates because it can only get better and better.

4/5 Amazing with potential.
