23620824.review:
[h1]Rodina - Tech-Demo oder doch mehr?[/h1]

Ich hab mich echt gefragt, warum dieses Spiel, was inhaltlich kaum mehr als eine sehr gute Tech-Demo bietet so gut bewertet ist? Die Antwort folgt nach der Auflistung dessen, was in der "Tech-Demo" enthalten ist.

Ihr startet auf einem Asteroid und kriegt dort die Einleitung für die Geschichte, fliegt ein Stück und holt euch eine Verbesserung für euer Schiff und dann gehts weiter.

Die Grafik ist schön, aber insgesamt ist alles sehr leer, für Asteroiden OK, bei Planeten ist es unglaublich langweilig, wenn dort nichts ist, außer Fels- bzw. Eislandschaften.
Ihr könnt und müsste eurem Schiff Verbesserungen geben und bekommt Munition für "bessere" Waffen. Viele Verbesserungen etc. sind das allerdings nicht.
Von außen sieht euer Schiff aus, wie ein Stein.
Der Innenraum sieht schon wesentlich besser aus, ihr könnt ihn auch gestalten, was in diesem Stadium des Spiels aber keinen Sinn oder gar Mehrwert bietet.
Das Sonnensystem und die Steuerung sind gut gemacht, die Entfernungen und die Größe der Objekte (Sonne, Planeten, Asteroiden) erscheinen realistisch, die Steuerung auch (tlw. Newtonsche Physik, Kampfe sind OK, Planetenlandung ist herausfordernd und insgesamt macht es Spaß das Schiff zu fliegen).

Interface ist zweckdienlich und ermöglicht eine gute Spielbarkeit des Spiels.

Es macht keinen Sinn die Gegner anzugreifen außer um an eine bestimmte Stelle zu kommen (bei Asteroiden) oder zum Spaß, ansonsten hat man nix davon. Selbst wenn sie abstürzen, so findet man nichts an ihrem Absturzort, außer eben das brennende Wrack. Irgendwann wird man sie einfach nur umgehen, was eher schade ist.

Soweit, es ist eben ein Early Acces-Spiel und wird auch nur von einer Person entwickelt.

Mit all dem wäre man eine vielleicht maximal 2h beschäftigt und dann würde es sehr sehr langweilig werden.

Wird es aber nicht und das liegt an der Geschichte und nur deswegen kann das als vollwertiges EarlyAcces-Spiel gewertet werden und nur deswegen lassen sich die 15 € rechtfertigen. Und auch nur wegen der Geschichte ist die Bewertung so gut.

Neben der Kerngeschichte, die ihr Stück für Stück entdeckt gibt es noch diverse Datenfragmente, die ihr an diversen Absturzstellen aufsammeln könnt. Mit diesen Zusatzinfos bekommt die Geschichte mehr Tiefe und teilweise ist es sehr lustig geschrieben (alles in Englisch). Die Geschichte ist sehr gut erzählt und echt spannend. Besonders dieser Punkt, wo ihr begreift ... aber ich will nicht vorgreifen. Entdeckt es selbst.

[b]Dieses Spiel ist +10 € wert und kriegt eine positive Bewertung, weil:[/b]

[list]
    [*]es trotz des EA bereits eine "runde Sache" ist
    [*]also ein abgeschlossenes, wenn auch kurzes (10h) Spielerlebnis bietet
    [*]die Spielmechanik gut und vielversprechend ist
    [*]die Story den Spieler gut mitnimmt und Tiefe hat
[/list]

Der momentane Fokus liegt voll auf der Story, wer das Spiel wegen Weltraumsim, Erforschen und Abenteuer kauft, der wird eher enttäuscht sein. Wer sich aber mal anschauen will, was es technisch bietet und sich dann auf eine gute Geschichte einlassen will, der ist hier richtig.

Ich hab die Geschichte gemütlich in 10h durchgespielt, könnte aber noch weiter forschen um mehr Neben- und Hintergrundinfos zu bekommen oder hätte das ganze auch deutlich schneller machen können. Aktueller durchschnittlicher Spielumfang ist also etwa 10h.

This is the best space game I have ever played, and it's only in early access. This is a truly amazing experience, and should be experienced by all sci-fi fans. I am obviously biased towards this game, but I shall try my best to display the pros and cons to this wonderful game.

PROS
-Seamless gameplay (no loading screens)
-Full scale solar system to explore (Sun, 4 planets (life size), and asteroid belt)
-Amazing soundtrack (Epic battle music!)
-Fun combat that requires movement (Sci-fi games usually line up the ships and have you wail at each other)
-Choice between 1st person and 3rd person (only while piloting the ship, I recommend 1st person)
-Variety of weapons and upgrades (note that the upgrades only negate negative planet enviroments)
-A decent variety of enemies
-A pretty good story
-Customizable ship
-Datastick collectables (expand upon the backstory/lore of the game)

CONS
-Enemies can drop fps due to the volume of particle effects. (doesn't really happen to me, I have a pretty beefy PC)
-Sometimes crashes (only happened to me once)
-All of the planets are just wastelands and mountains. (From what I know, this is being worked on, but isn't there yet)

If you are thinking about trying this game out, there is a FREE demo available. There are no restrictions to the game in the demo, just a 1 hour limit to play time.

Well. It definitely has potential, but some major flaws are noticed early game.  The landing is a bit awkward. Even when I use the docking speed and very fine tuning with the strafe/FWD/BCKWD to bring her down.. it's just that the ship seems weightless.  It wont stick to the ground in most situtations. It's almost bouncy even on a very very soft landing.  

The other problem was the first planet I visit- it's littered with marks all over as you approach, indicating plenty of areas to explore.  But you have to enter the atmosphere at an angle, and there's no telling how long it'll take, so there's really no way to aim your way to a good spot.  So now I'm on the planet.... and I'm cruising. endlessly.  10 minutes go by- nothing but the same landscape. None of the points of interest show locally, nor am i finding any at cruise speed (the highest you can go in the atmosphere).  Another 10-15 minutes goes by and at this point I've put down the game. I'm all for exploring  and all- but not when there's so little to explore.  My suggestion would be to keep some of the local marks on screen so you can move toward them, instead of zig-zagging around aimlessly for half an hour, still finding nothing.

When I finally got a liminal drive, the game told me I should explore some planet named Jarilo. Planets, you say? Too boring! I decided to check out the sun instead.

I got too close and burned up. Reloaded. Tried to rocket away, but this close to the sun its gravity was inescapable. Burned up again. Reloaded. Now my respawn point was so close to the sun that I kept burning up in seconds.

Since I would have to restart the game, I decide to perform a final gesture. In my next reload I left the ship pilot screen, walked through my spaceship, opened my airlock and jumped out. My ship dropped away from me and I was left alone, falling into a sun that would soon inevitably consume me.

10/10 would be consumed by the sun again

23350778.review:
An amazing hidden gem that I would recommend buying to any and all stargazers.

First off: I'll mention the main point anyone would give a negative review on this game. There is a major lack of content. While this is a valid point (and basically the only valid point), it is completely and totally offset by the many positive factors.

Now, to the billion GOOD reasons to buy this game
1) The Developer: ERMUHGURD! The developer! This is a one man team (hence the lack of content) and should be judged in accordance, but he works with the speed of ten. I got this game probably around 2 years ago and since then this game has changed in more ways than I could imagine, this is even better because the content changes didn't morph the game that I had come to love, but like a gem, it has slowly been chipped and polished so it can shine even brighter. Plus, if you are worrying about the game being caught in early access hell, A) did you even read what I wrote? and B) the dev has proven to be extremely aware of this issue, that is why he made the demo and seems to offer refunds to any unsatisfied customers (THATS how consumer-friendly he is)

2) The Soundtrack: Just... Just play the game and you will know exactly what Im talking about it. As any good Syfi anything, the music is soo epic and fits the tone perfectly. Speaking of...

3) The Tone: The best way I can describe the tone of this game is like the early days of minecraft. It is often overlooked just how lonely that game can feel. When you arent playing with anyone, you really get the feeling that while minecraft, with its haunting piano track and all the unkown factors, gives you unlimited freedom, it comes with this soul freezing feeling of lonelines. Rodina uses its epic soundtrack and scale to bring you the same affect. Oh I almost forgot about the scale!

4) Scale: This is probably one of the only games I have ever owned that made me comprehend much better something that would usually be considered incomprehensible in ways only a video game could. This game made me grasp just how vast and empty space really is while still making it an enjoyable experience throught how the game progression curve and the sheer size. I'm trying to avoid anecdotes because I truley belive that this game needs to be experienced first hand, but ill say this. It makes you feel like a flea.

5) Combat: While it does take some time to get used to the controls of flying in 0G, the intuitiveness of the game is unprecedented for games of its caliber. While Im flinging around in a death spin with other games of similar physics, I'm able to fly around relatively accurately in Rodina.

If that doesnt convince you I dont know what will...

23060469.review:
[b]Early access - will be judged accordingly[/b]

[b]What Is Rodina?[/b]
Rodina is, as it stands, an open sandbox where the player flies around in their ship shooting bad guys and collecting robotic companions. There is sparse story through message logs and no story yet implemented to drive the game. The ship interior is customisable allowing the player to edit the interior aesthetic however they like, although this serves little purpose.

[b]So is it good?[/b]
Rodina is enjoyable, it allows you to wander around dogfighting and exploring as much as you wish, but the sandbox has to little in it to make it interesting. The ship mechanics whilst not true to life with the star-trek jargon 'Liminal drive' is still interesting and makes space flight much easier than it would be in a sim (eg Kerbal Space Program). Planetary landing is a nice feature with atmospheric descent threatanigh to blow up your [strike]sh*t[/strike] ship through re-entry heat.

[b]Is it bad?[/b]
As with many early access titles this game is a good basis for a larger game that has more depth to it, so whilst Rodina may be a good game with (what I can tell by other reviews is) a good dev, Rodina's early access left me underwhelmed. Updates are a bit sporadic so it's hard to know when you will see a full release after 2 years in early access.

For £11 Rodina is a somewhat justifiable purchase

23050274.review:
(While it says only 2 hours in the game, I have played the demo for a bit longer) 

    This work of art has to be one of the most peaceful games I have ever played! Thanks to a rich score, beautiful  starry sky, and simple machanics, you can loose yourself in this game. The premise is that you are the only human from the   large inter-galactic mothership called "Rodina" (hence the name) in the system and it is your mission to rid the the area of Xeno's (Alien creatures). Now, you can complete the main mission as your sole objective, but the game is all about exploring and flight. The game is still fairly new, and the developer (Yes one developer) is slowly updating and adding new features to make it better. But what it lacks in content, it makes up for in detail and scale (Each planet and asteroid in game is full size).    CONS: the guy (or gal) runs too damn fast, so sometimes you fall off your boarding ramp(SHIFT: fixes this =P)

23050044.review:
IS THIS NO MANS SKY? ...no! This game has been on my wish list for a long time and finally bought it (at full price like a crazy gamer shouldn't do for early access games). The devs have been active on the forums (and with updates) and the concept of being able to move about my ship and on the planet is an amazing concept. Any Star Trek, Star Wars or space fan will enjoy this game. Although quite limited in it's early stages, [url=https://elliptic-games.com/?page_id=738]the dev has a huge plan to implement possible one of the best space games ever[/url]. 

Rodina is this Star Trek's fan biggest dream game. I have played Star Trek Bridge Commander (and thoroughly enjoyed the gameplay, storyline and graphics) and yearned to walk around the ship. Rodina brings this fantasy to reality with it's concept. The devs are really specific in saying that this is a seamless space game, meaning there are no loading screens. The player can walk around their ship, pilot their ship, get off their ship, get off the planet and onto the ship without any loading processes. The absolute first feature players will notice is that they are able to walk anywhere around their ship. There is only one ship at the moment but there is a small modding community that offer different ship designs. These mods are not flawless and some may need special attention to get working properly (in-game and out of game). The player may design and change the inside of the ship at any time. If you would like a bigger bridge, bigger room, bigger hallways, that can be done with a few simple clicks. The design menu isn't super friendly but does provide the player with basics to design what they want. What is a neat feature is that the player may remotely control the ship from certain panels. For example, say you don't want to walk to the cockpit every time you would like to pilot the ship. There is a panel located by the air-lock located on the back of the ship for the players convenience. That by itself showed me there was some serious thought put into the game.

The player may fly the ship in almost any direction and can pilot/interact with panels by pressing "F". WASD allows the player to move as well as steer the ship. Spacebar allows the player to jump while allowing the ship to move upwards on the z axis. There is no crouching ability (I'm assuming yet) but CTRL will move the ship downwards on the z-axis. The controls/sensitivity can be modified for your preference. Some secondary weapons can be picked up on stray planets or asteroids and can be equipped by pressing R. There is no first person mode to shoot as of yet but there may be plans in the future. The devs haven't singled out many suggestions but are keeping to their road map and are focusing on a campaign. Tab will allow the player to switch between first person and third person view. This is only possible while piloting the ship. Left button will fire the ships weapons while the right mouse button acts as the clutch (in which the player will need to press up or down to switch between drive systems). Some drives will need to be picked up by the player by exploring. Currently, I have experienced four drives in which the fourth will let you travel at light speed. Piloting and landing have been made relatively easy to do. The ship will approach a planet/asteroid and slowly start adjusting itself as you attempt to adjust yourself to the horizon. Leaving the planet to travel is also equally as easy but entering will require some skill as the atmosphere may burn you and your ship up! Quick! Grab the fire extinguisher!

There are no significant or diverse NPC's at the moment but this is on the agenda. There are a few enemies you will encounter upon traveling the stars. The [b]campaign[/b] as of now consists of the player starting on a barren rock, finding their ship then collecting some materials (such as crates, weapons - limited, diary logs and technology) then traveling to the next planet. The player then may choose where they wish to go next. Most planets will have enemies defending it as well as cargo on it (be it logs, weapons or empty crates). There is a minor story line that the player can follow but will require them to decipher certain messages while other messages can be simply read. [b]Graphics[/b] remind me of minecraft but there is an HD mod out there to help improve the visuals. I personally hope there will be a significant upgrade in this realm. [b]Sounds[/b] are basic at the moment and do not vary much. All the fundamentals are there though!

Overall, the game seems promising although limited at the moment. Hardcore space fans will find hours of fun in this early access while regular gamers may be waiting for a full release to come out. Early access is a tricky gamble but I've bought the game in hopes that this will become a great game. I will give it a recommendation but will advise players that they should really do their homework before buying.


EARLY ACCESS RATING : 6.85/10

23028035.review:
Took a couple of hours of play to really sink in, but Rodina even in its current form is one of my all-time favorite gaming experiences.
Very immersive space exploration game with realistic planetary and solar scale. The graphics appear to be very plain and flat from the screenshots, but the beautiful lighting and atmospheric effects combine to provide breathtaking scenery, underscored by an unexpectedly powerful soundtrack of orchestral and synth space music which makes simply orbiting at speed above a planet feel profoundly emotional.

The game is rather simple to play, and does a good job of leading you from quest to quest. The story presented so far at this stage of development is impressively thought-provoking and engaging, a legit science fiction epic inpsired by masters such as Azimov, Clarke and Kurzweil, with surprises for the player that deserve not to be spoiled.

The controls are direct and unencumbered by over-simulation, and allow you to pilot you ship with full 6 degrees of freedom and utilize your momentum to perform satisfying maneuvers. Usually control setup and familiarization is the biggest hurdle to getting into a 3D spaceflight game, however Rodina's controls and GUI are extremely accessible, arcade-like even. 

An interesting feature is the various "gears" you can put your ship in to control speed: a slow speed for landing, a faster speed for combat, full cruising speed at which you cannot use weapons, and ultimately a giddy and scale-accurate lightspeed where the distance between objects in light-seconds is the precise amount of time it takes you to get there. Each speed setting is essentially an order of magnitude faster than the last. This system works very well to permit easy transition between the fine control needed for negotiating a landing and the coarse adjustments needed for interplanetary travel, as well as getting the hell outta Dodge when necessary.

Unlilke many starfighter games, the ship does not pilot exactly like a fighter plane, but much more like the agile ship from the Descent games, and so combat can be approached with lateral strafing and reverse-thrust distancing against smaller, faster enemies, while larger, slower enemies are best circled and then rushed from the side. You can also switch to the fastest cruising speed momentarily to outrun missile locks and enemy aim, swing around and attack from the flank. The combat is solid, although more enemy ship types such as huge battleships would be nice down the line.

Currently there is only ship-to-ship battle, although it appears that personal combat and invasion of enemy ships and bases is the next significant addition slated, which will certainly add new depth. 
There are several weapons you can acquire to fill out your ship's arsenal, from fire-and-forget missiles and bullet swarms to slow, heavy-hitting cannons. Nothing terribly incredible but a quite adequate variety to handle the 4 or 5 enemy types I've found, from light to heavy armor, each specializing in equivalent weapons to those you obtain.

The story is rather short currently, I completed the main questline in a day in which I found myself incrementally engrossed in the adventure with each upgrade and story log, but I was completely satisfied with what I was able to play, and am eagerly looking forward to the additional content laid out in the development roadmap. 
There are many things that Rodina is not, at least currently. It is not a space trading game, or survival game, or simulation game, or a relentless high-action shooter. It is a very relaxing exploration adventure that lets you tackle the mystery of the Zorica star system at your own pace and contains all the necessary elements to make it worth the trip.

And if you're looking for something to sate you until No Man's Sky, this is your best bet (although they will end up being totally different games in the future).

22990727.review:
What Rodina currently lacks in detail and content, it makes up for in scale. When you hover over planets and even minor asteroids for the first time, you don't understand what you're looking at. No really, because of the lack of any features on planets other than small textures, you won't comprehend that the hill you think you're looking at is a miles high mountain part of a mountain range that when viewed from space looks like a small blemish. That's where Rodina shines, when you get down to the surface of planets and strafe left and right until you realize that those mountains you were whizzing by in your shuttle aren't moving anymore. These are real planets when it comes to scale, in an also vast solar system. The planets themselves, mixed with asteroids of various shapes and sizes are fun to explore for a few hours, expecially coupled with the game's amazing, if not slightly repetitive soundtrack.
The story is interesting, considering it is told through Datasticks, and encryption keys you find throughout the various planets and asteroids. The main story unfolds through the Pilot Wave Radio on your ship. There is no exposition, or dialogue choices, so if you're not interested in reading I would recommend you simply play freeform mode (you can still pick up Datasticks). The story at the time of this review is unfinished and cuts off (you get an in game message telling you this). If the story hasn't been spoiled for you yet, play through the game and experience it yourself.
The combat is simple at this time. There are a few enemy types that you will encounter, from small scout fighters up to battleships. Your primary weapon is a fast shooting and unlimited laser. There are other weapons you unlock throughout the game by finding containers of their respective ammo. I usually stuck with the starting weapon. Some of the enemies can be simple with practice, while other enemies could use some tweaks.
Your ship, an (as far as I know) unnamed "Gunship" is a modified human shuttle. It is the medium through which you experience Rodina. To reflect this, the interior of the ship is modular, meaning you can customize it with a generous amount of layouts, props, usable items, and decorations. I say generous as this game is far from complete and I was pleasantly surprised with the amount of options we have at this time. 
Overall, Rodina is a great game, and will be even better with future updates. Thanks for reading.

Firstly, flying through space is all well and good.  Going through atmosphere's can be fun also.  However the planet landscape is where it kind of kills it for me.  For the most part its pretty much the same landscapes just different colours.

I don't really write reviews much, but after experiencing what I just experienced, I felt an obligation to do so. This game is beautiful in every possible way. I just got to what was originally the end of the story, however the developer is still adding to it. So let's go down the basics, starting from (in my opinion) the least important pieces, to the best part of this game.

1. Graphics:

Quite obviously, the least important part, but a part anyways. The graphics are a bit simplistic, but they get the job done and actually fit in nicely with the rest of the game.

2. Bugs:

Now, this game is only being worked on by one person, and if you keep up with their developer's updates, you'd know that they're going through quite a rough point in their lives right now. That being said, this game is practically bug free. It's amazing how polished this game is [b]especially[/b] considering the developers current personal status. I've experienced a total of 2 bugs in this game, and one of them was a crash. Okay, to be fair, the game has crashed twice, but I didn't even lose any progress, thanks to this games marvelous autosave function. The other bug was a graphical bug. I found a strange wall in a ditch on one of the planets. I assume this was caused because of the textures being combined at the edge of the planet. It's like folding a flat blanket over a sphere, you can still see the seams. However, as soon as I was far enough, I couldn't even see the bug anymore. 

-Addition: I just tried edditing my ship to make a few changes, and in the entities catagory, no matter what I choose (Move, rotate, or delete), I can only rotate an entity. The statement above still apply, however.

3. Sountrack:

The soundtrack to this game is gorgeous, and stunning. I love every bit of it. It fills you with exactly the same feeling that the rest of this game does: a feeling of being alone, but not upset, or sad, but joyful. It's hard to explain how you can be so lonely without feeling any sort of bleakness.

4. Gameplay:

This subject will be split into multiple parts, as there's a lot to cover.

I - On planet/asteroid travel:
This is the first part of the game that you experience, and the part that you get the least of. It's easy to understand, only using the standard WASD controls, F to activate things, G activates a flashlight, press space to jump, and press space again to activate a jetpack. You'll only really be in this mode for a few seconds when collecting this out of the ship, and to activate a few things inside the ship. Easy to understand, simple and easy, not overused, and a good addition to the game. 

II - Flight/solar system travel:
The most common part of the game. There are four different flight speeds, all of which you unlock within the first 30 minutes of playtime. It has a very responsive control system that's very satisfying to use. There are also scanners that you can place inside your ship. These act as a map to help guide you through the massive solar system. 

III - Combat:
This can be really easy, or really hard depending mostly on one variable: the number of enemies. Though the combat is just a responsive as the flight system and very satisfying, the enemy A.I. is very limited and not very advanced. Taking on anything from one to six is a walk in the park, while seven and up will have you tearing your hair out. This is due to how the enemies attack. With no self preservation, they just come flying at you shooting the whole time. This, however, isn't that bad, considering that their top speed is the equivelant of your second speed, so in the event that you need to retreat, or go to the other side of all the enemies, it is easy to do so. 

IV - Ship customization:
This part was a lot of fun for me. It may depend on how much you like customization, but personally, I would not recommend using the default ship, so customization is almost a manditory part of the game. The game allows you to load up an empty map and go to town with every tool at your disposal. A tutorial for some, would be nice, but I found no problem with picking everything up. Customizing your ship adds value and care for it. It makes it feel like it's really [i]your[/i] ship. I might not have liked this game nearly as much were it not for the ship customization.

5. Story:
This part is what inspired me to write this. I will not say anything about it, except that you have to read the encrypted messages. The encrypted messages are the main story, everything else is just fluff. Quite nice fluff, but just fluff. If you have not had this game spoiled yet, you have to buy this game now. Do not look up the story. Go into it completely blind; you'll thank me later.

That concludes this review. If I had to rate this game, I would give it a 9.8/10. I have to take that .2 off because of the few and far between bugs, and slightly dodgy graphics, but I hardly noticed any of that. I love this game and would recommend it to anyone who will give me five seconds to talk. Buy it now.

21741111.review:
This is a fun game with considerable potential.

Rodina definitely succeeded in making me feel like the captain of my own spaceship, going on adventures that only loosely felt like it had all been scripted by someone.

The game's story is clever in content and execution.  It's clear about events yet cryptic how you fit in.  It goes at your own pace and you don't know who to trust, and is topped off with a plot twist I didn't see coming.

The story is presented to you in such a way that you feel like an observer looking in, if it weren't for the fact that the game tells you you're involved, but not how.  The story isn't forced upon you, either.  You can discover it at your own pace, along with side stories, some funny, some intriguing, some dark, and some all at once.

Combat never gets old.  You're flying around super fast to catch and satisfyingly shoot down aliens while avoiding their fire and defensively blasting their missiles, making you feel like a space ninja.

The game has many small but really neat details.  Defeated alien ships will crash land into any nearby planet.  Entering the atmosphere will jostle the camera and surround your ship with flames until you've finally entered the atmosphere, accompanied with the perfect sound effect while fully revealing the beauty of the new world.  You can customize the interior of your ship.  You can pilot it in first or third person.  You can leave it running and walk around in your ship, and even jump out of it or open the airlock to quench flames in emergencies when your extinguishers aren't enough.

There's more to this early access game, but I'm not gonna spoil any more.  Give this game a try.

21423318.review: This game... this freaking amazing of a game. Rodina is a space exploration game, with enimies that you can shoot down to take over a planet. There are 4 planets (Hopefully there will be more in the future) that you can visit and land on. Although in the spaceship that you fly around in makes everything seem small, YOU'RE SO WRONG. SO SO SO WRONG. The sense of scale in this game is far past anygame that I've ever seen. Infact, the spaceship itself is about the size of a house. The mountains are gigantic, in the sense it takes 30 minutes+ to climb some of the tallest ones. You have a jetpack that lets you fly around as well, which is very fun. The game has three main modes, Normal, Freeform, and Peaceful. Normal is more or less the main story of the game, in which you can easily die. Freeform is basically the creative mode, although you can still die in it. And I haven't played peaceful, so I'm not sure what that is about. The games graphics are kind of polished-pixelated. They look amazing but can run on most computers, even if you have a potato. And you may think the "No loading screens" in the game description is false, IT'S NOT. The only loading screen I've ever seen in this game is the one that you get once you boot up the game, which, loads very very quickly. So, it's a very nice game, it's a little bit limited on the planets, but hopefully more will be added. This game is wroth $15. If you like Space Engineers, Space Engine, Universe Sandbox 2, or Sol 0, get this game!

20901871.developer_response:
Sorry to hear about the performance issues! I programmed the engine myself so it can be rough around the edges at times :D

Please check out the options menu near the bottom for some performance tweaks.

"Terrain Creation Rate" - this can really help periodic hitches. I recommend turning it down, though it will make terrain update more slowly.
"Terrain Detail" - might help a bit to turn this down, but maybe not.
"Planet Map Generation Quality" - will help lag when you first arrive at a planet
"Retro Mode" - nuclear option! Guaranteed to make the game run much better ;) But it makes the game look like its from 1994

I know that's not a full solution but I hope that helps!

PS: Also feel free to shoot me an email at brendan@elliptic-games.com to let me know how it went or if you need more help!

20609052.review:
I find it hard to reccomend games that are in Early Access. Many are usually more or less incomplete games, so Early Access, for many games, is essentially an excuse for Beta testing without having to pay anyone. However, there are some games that are a full, complete game even in early access, and provide new and interesting content untill the developers feel it's ready to fully release. Rodina is NOT one of these games. So the question is, why do I reccomend it so much?

The answer is simple: Rodina is a very open, very easty-to-play, and very fun game, and will one day be something amazing.

As it stands, the world is very baron and empty, with only a few game mechanics involved, which includes flying around, collecting things on the surface of planets and asteriods and flying. I wouldn't callt his a complete game at all. However, what is in there are plots with a dark sense of humour, as well as what is so far an interesting main narritive which, althought it can be hard to follow at times, keeps you wanting to find more things.

But easily the main reason i'd reccomend this game is atmospheare. This game has such an immense sense of scale, that coming right up to the sun and seeing its size actually made me feel ill it looked that big. And the flying mechanics are absolutely great too. And planets are planet-sized. You could fit the GTA5 map on the smallest plannet dozens of times over with ease. Each planet has a unique feel to it and all are worth exploreing, as long as you can get past the enemies.

This is where we reach the weakest part of the game: the combat. I am really dissapointed too, because this is finally a game that makes me feel like i'm flying around in 3-D space without having to learn too many complex controls and yet the combat system is so broken. Perhaps I am simply bad at the game, but the enemies take way too long to die, and the extra weapons you find on the ground are very limited and either don't add a whole lot or are pretty much required to stand even a chance at beating them.

But again, this is where I still want to keep reccomending the game. I know for a fact that the combat system is going to be improved eventually, and I am sure that it'll be better and more diverse. I have a lot of faith in this game and I would at least reccomend getting the free demo, to see if it's the sort of game you'd like.

In conclusion, while most Early Access games are a game which feels like a tech demo, this Early Access game is basically a tech demo which feels like a game. Pick it up now, because over time I feel that this game will start getting really good, and the price may go up.

20501328.review:
RECOMMENDED ONCE IT GETS OUT OF EARLY ACCESS

For the record, the developer has said the game won't just stop being updated once that happens; it's gonna be perpetual like Minecraft & Destiny, which is one of the few trends today that I quite like. Once it's out of EA there should be enough content to really get a full experience out of this game. Until then, it's a bit empty. 

The game as is:
It's in the same vein as Elite: Dangerous and what I assume No Man's Sky will be like. The majority of your time will be spent cruising through space, scouring planets and astroids for resources and clues to your mission. There is the occasional space-dog-fight which are surprisingly challenging. From what I've gathered in the story so far, you're tasked to prevent your system from invasion by some hostile alien race (they don't show up for quite some time, so your mission is to prepare). As is, it works; there's enough context to your actions without the story overriding the natural wonder of exploration. 

There's not much to do, but the core gameplay of exploring terain and flying in space works, so if that sounds like your thing, it's 100% worth your time and money.

20480186.review:
Frontier Developments (The Elite:Dangerous devs) should hire whoever wrote the story to just leave small bits of awesomely written text all over their universe.
Seriously, this is a fun game and it works well and you can shoot stuff but what i truly found to stand out most here is the great writing. I don't remember many games where i was actually excited to read flavour texts and random logs. While the story is not overly original (also not overly generic) the writing makes this game weirdly human, even though it looks a little bit like something from 1998, and its very easy to feel immersed.
This immersion is also supported by a very minimalistic sound design and the shifting mechanic which IMO is also a pretty fun way to handle the controls.
This plus mod support and a dev who is clearly very devoted to his work makes Rodina a game that will not develop quickly but has an amazing amount of potential and is already very fun to play.
This barebone graphics game gave me more immersion into its universe than Elite:Dangerous did in 40 hours, once again proving that spending millions on the most perfect TSXXSSAOMSAA and 50k textures will never replace a well written text, crafted by someone who has something to say.

19225704.review:
This game perfectly encapsulates why I love space but don't actually want to go there. The "reading about the best parts at home" and "actually going to space" sides are equally interesting. Rodina makes space realistically boring in this fashion. You can see mountains the size of continents, but they still look like piles of red dirt once you get over their size. You can see canyons miles deep that circle entire planets, but they're mostly the same westward as eastward. You can see 10,000 large space rocks but they're all more or less pointless unless you find the one that's only the size of Connecticut. You can see purple skies and a green sun just as easily as yellow skies and a blue sun, and both look equally routine after spending enough time under both. Warp into the sun accidentally, and you'll get a quick laugh. Warp into someplace that isn't the sun and wonder what you'll find. Hit planetside without dieing and your reward is an endless desert, as not-really-picturesque as the REAL Saharan Desert, as it stretches on samily for all of the miles. Maybe you can find some fun rocks, but you have to sift through a billion tons of rainbow dirt to find it. Shooting aliens gets normal after you figure out how to start shooting at max range and backpedaling. The game is boring, but rightfully so because if it was always interesting then it'd be unrealistic. Just remember: Lotta dirt to look through to find that rock in that one episode of Star Trek that bill and Ted parodied.



Seriously though warping into the sun never gets old.

18980833.review:
Rodina is a space exploration game set within a single solar system.  The music is pleasant and the writing is well done (the interview with Malcolm McCreedy is my personal favorite).  The single quest line will likely take you a couple of hours to complete, unless you rush through it.  The interior of your space craft is fully customizable within the game.  The exterior of the ship may be 'modded' with third-party tools, and a number of modded ships are available from fan sites.

Combat is unrewarding, beyond a personal satisfaction.  There are no 'experience points' to earn, and destroyed enemies drop no loot.  Combat is practically optional, as groups of enemies are easy to navigate around.  This allows you to decide if your gaming experience will be "guns blazing" or exploration.

The game is a work in progress, and the developer is very active in the game's community.  Based on his forum posts and his own description of the game, the developer clearly has big plans for Rodina.  In its current state, you may expect to "run out of things to do" after a day or two of game play.  Once you have completed the quest line and discovered all of the data modules, all that's left is combat and sight seeing.  

I recommend this game because I sincerely enjoy playing it.  I find myself smiling as I travel from planet to planet, and I found the short stories entertaining and diverse.  Rodina is a refreshing game with a bright future that is worth experiencing and supporting.

18979245.review:
Oh...oh...my goodness. I just finished the storyline as far as it goes at the moment, and I'm just sitting here in awe. Forget any other purchases you were going to make, buy this game right now. You will not regret it.


For a more in-depth review:

Rodina is a retro-style space sim done in an open-world style, meaning that you can fly about an entire actual size solar system with no loading screens. It's a bit thin on features at the moment, but it's still Early Access, and in my experience has been incredibly stable for an Early Access title.

Graphics/SFX: 8/10
Graphics are kind of retro-styled, but still look quite good, with terrain textures being fairly detailed, ship interiors looking AWESOME, and sound effects being perfect for this type of game. However, the exterior of your ship is somewhat bland (the ship design can apparently be edited in 3D modeling programs, so if you would like, I believe this can be changed), and planet terrain mostly consists of cliffs, hills, and mountains, with no vegetation or anything to make them feel more "real". This is perfectly acceptable in an Early Access game imo, but it's worth noting.

Soundtrack: 10/10
GET THE SOUNDTRACK, TOO. I'm serious. The Rodina OST is one of the most beautiful pieces of work I've ever heard, perfectly meshing with the gameplay. Flying between asteroids? The music is nice and peaceful, capturing the awe of just staring at the beauty of the universe. Moving into combat? The music shifts to adrenaline-inducing battle music. It's a masterpiece equaled in only a handful of other games I've played. My top three game soundtracks are (in no particular order): FTL, Risk of Rain, and Rodina.

Gameplay/Story: 9/10
Words cannot describe it, because it's so freaking AWESOME. The only reason that it misses out on a perfect score is the fact that it's currently unfinished. The combination of listening to the awesome soundtrack while reading the incredibly emotional dialogue in the encrypted communications...beautiful.

Overall: 9/10
A beautiful work by a very talented developer, missing out on a perfect score only due to the unfinished nature of the game. This is the only game I've ever bought at list price, and I have zero regrets. The developer seems committed to further progress on the game, and I'm confident in wholeheartedly recommending this game. If you're considering getting it, stop considering and start buying!

18781697.review:
With the reviews on Steam, I purchased this game thinking there must be something I was missing in the videos.  Maybe the game truly was "life altering?"  

Sadly, no.  Even the developer himself says, "However, there isn't currently enough content or gameplay. That's what I'm working on right now!”

He couldn't be more correct.  It's semi neat to fly from one planet to the next, but this is becoming old hat in modern video games.  Other than that, there's really little to no gameplay at all right now.  Fly to a planet.  Find a + sign.  Land.  Collect empty crates, empty barrels (neither of which currently seem to do anything) some missiles and a couple of pink crystals.  One will let you continue the storyline in the form of encrypted e-mails which you read, and the other will give you a data entry of some passingly interesting letters collected from the previous inhabitants, which you read.  Fly to next + sign, shoot bad guys with the missiles, rinse repeat.  

I played the game for two hours with no change.  If there's anything new introduced later, then the game has pacing issues.  If not, it's just not enough content for a $15 game.  Perhaps in the future it will be, and at that point I'll revise this review.  

But as it is, my rule of thumb is that I should get about $0.50 per hour play time out of a game.  (Thus if I pay $50 for a game, it should be roughly 100 hours of play time.)   As this game cost $15, and I got less than 2 hours out of it, I can't currently give it my recommendation.

18492483.review:
This game is still very, very early access, but for what it's worth it's one of the few amazing early access games on the store. 

Basically the objective of the game is to fly around in your own customisable spaceship, around to other nearby planets to collect data, logs or an assortment of upgrades.

There are also enemies littered around the planets (and even asteroids) that will attempt to kill you. The combat system can be rather tricky, but overall it's very fun.

There's also a system in place that allows you to set the speed of your own ship. You have a choice between "Docking Speed", "Combat Speed", and "Cruising Speed". There's another speed modifier you can find via exploration called "Limnal Speed" which allows you to travel at, what else? Light speed!

There's tons to do in this game as well. Including landing on planets/asteroids! When you're near a planet (with an atmosphere) you will begin atmospheric re-entry. This is a little 'minigame' in which you attempt to keep your ship at a proper angle and speed to avoid it being damaged by the heat. This heat can also spark fires in your ship, but don't worry! There's a handy fire extinguisher for you just in case.

Once you land on a planet, exiting it is very simple. Simply point up and out. However be wary of the enemies that surround the planets in this game. They're far more common on the planets themselves instead of asteroids and WILL hunt you down! 

There's already tons of things to do in this game, and it's not even finished yet! I would highly recommend this game to anyone who's looking for a laid-back space exploration game. There's plenty of sandbox to go around. Just steer clear of the star.

18372808.review:
There's no greater praise I can give this game than it reminds of a type of game I haven't seen very often in all my 30+ years of gaming. Mercenary. Damocles. Mercenary III. Starglider 1 and especially 2. Great writing coupled with amazing visuals and such incredible SCOPE....Rodina is the first game to make me think those superlative early works of art weren't forgotten. Someone REMEMBERED.

Rodina is beautiful. Beautiful to play, to experience and to marvel at in the same way we marvel at paintings hanging in galleries. The simplicity of its controls, the fact you have a vast solar system as your playground, the simulated elements like fire and way I can actually get blown out of an airlock (first time that happened the REAL me nearly stopped breathing!). The way the simple aesthetic fuses every element together into a cohesive whole. this game is amazing fun to play, beautiful to look at, wonderfully constructed and just BEGGING to be expanded upon.

Finding this game was like finding a lost Shakespearean sonnet. Welcome back, ghosts of all those game authors who dared to dream worlds.

[UPDATE] If there's one caveat to the game it's this: the game isn't finished. What's there is amazing but there's a lot to do to broaden the experience. The developer has great plans for the game but it may be some time before this game's full potential is realised.

18034737.review:
I typically do not write reviews, however this game has inspired me to do otherwise.

What you may have gathered from reading the description of the game or other reviews, is that "Rodina" is a seamless open world RPG in space. While this is entirely correct, it does little justice for this masterpiece's true nature. Few, if any, games capture the true isolation and vastness of space. The in game planets are, well, planet sized, and the distance between them feels very real. Combine this with a stellar sound track and a unique visual style, and you have a truly great enviroment. That is without even mentioning the story and combat aspects, which are both executed nearly flawlessly.
However, before I end this review it would be misleading if I did not cover the games flaws. The game is still in development and therefore not perfect. The developer is very open to the community and is extremely active on the  Rodina Subreddit; a great model for all indev games. The game's story currently resolves itself fairly well, but is in fact not entirely complete. And while the in game world is massive and beautiful, it is still largely unpoulated. Thankfully, the game is regularly updated and the dev often shares with the community his latest addition's development.

In all, Rodina seems to have nearly limitless potential right now, and while I can't garuntee you will like this game, I can garuntee that for me, Rodina has been one of the most enjoyable experiences I've had in a game

17823544.review:
Even as millions of dollars are constantly being funneled into Star Citizen's production, Cloud Imperium's proven team of engineers and artists reach for the Holy Grail of space simulation that the single developer of Rodina has already claimed. What Rodina lacks in visual polish and superficial content, it more than makes up for with a flawlessly seamless harmony between interstellar, planetary, and ship-based gameplay. Ever wanted the ability to fight hull fires in your custom made ship as it plummeted rapidly through the atmosphere of an undiscovered planet? That I know of, Rodina is the only space simulator currently with that capacity.

Good - You'll get a space flight sim experienced that you've only been able to fantasize. This is what Star Citizen and Elite: Dangerous hope to be some day.

Bad - The game is still in tentative development, and as such, lacks many secondary and tertiary features that ought to populate a gamespace as open and as unhindering as Rodina's. Rest assured, however, that the developer is working on truly solid foundations, and given time, Rodina will be soaked with features.

17821135.review:
The game has a ton of potential, but I think the developer bit off more than he can chew. 

The combat and gameplay are fun and have a unique feel. The customization features are also a nice touch. However, the game still feels like a canvas rather than anything close to a finished product. I felt that I had exhausted most of the game's features after only a few hours of play. Months later, after first purchasing the game, little has changed. 

I only regret buying it now because it seems that at the current pace of development it will take several years for this game to reach its potential. By that time, I'll have moved on to other things.

17699783.review:
I am going to start out by saying that I hardly EVER write reviews. 

Lets start with the pros:

This game features a completely full-scale solar system with a few planets to explore, each incomprehensible in size until you really get close to them, they are actually quite f-ing massive, which is awesome.

The story is rich in text, and the lack of any spoken dialogue is actually great, because it adds a mysteriousness to the whole situation of the game (like who/what you are, why you are on this random mission)

The amount of places to explore are seemingly endless. 

Lots of baddies to fight, which gets quite challenging.

Being able to customize your ship to your liking is really something, and it is pretty easy to use.
(HOLO SCREENS FOR THE WIN!)

Okay, the concerns:

The game is quite short, but does not fall as a negative because this game is still early access, and is quite well built to begin with

The lands of planets do seem a bit barren, it would be nice if there were enemy/human outposts that could be attained or whatnot, but then again, still early access

Strange performance issue: Okay ive had this a few times, and what happens is that for no apparent reason, my video card maxes out and tries to push over 85 Celsius which is well over what I ever want it to be. Doesnt make sense, considering this game is low graphics and I can run Crysis 3 at max. Unfortunately I have no means to prove this, and it happens so rarely that a quick save and reboot of the game fixes it (still kinda unweary about it though)

Sometimes the GUI disappears after combat/piloting ship in first person, quick save and restart fixes it.

Overall: 
    I had tried the demo, instantly got hooked and played until the timer went out, purchased the game the moment I could, and have no regrets. This game is a fantastic open-world (or should I say, Open f-ing solar system) game with some serious potention added to its already fantastic gameplay physics and immersive storyline. Hope to see more in the future. 

If you have doubts, don't have doubts. And if you DO have doubts, at least get the demo to test those doubts. This game is fantastic.

17374519.review:
Fly anywhere!
Explore anywhere!
Die anywhere!

 This game is a bloody masterpiece, and it's still in development, so there's a lotta potential here. The game mixes amzing exploration with a brilliant, and kinda sad, story which, as someone who usually doesn't read anyhting in games, excited me and challenged me to put the pieces together. This is definitely worth buying if the idea of loadingscreen-less exploration, life sized planets, awesome story telling, and sci-fi themed games excite you. If not buy it anyways as it's quite fun to spam missiles at a group of enemy ships and watch them explode and burn.

Other good things about this:
-Retro mode! Over the age of ten? Miss retro video games? Gotta shit pc? Fear not, with retro mode you can increase the pixel size to whatever you want (within the range of 2 to 8)  which is pretty great if you use a potato as your pc.
-The dev. Yeah, it's odd but he seems to be one of the best devs ever. Just look at the comments on the negative reviews. So if you buy it and you decide it's pretty crap but you can't get a refund of Steam, it seems the dev is happy to help. Also the things he's planning sound great, so keep up the good work.
-The emergency open all doors button. In the middle of space? Have the burning desire to be thrown out your ship? This button's for you. Just plonk down a control panel and go on the ship tab, have fun!
-The fix player button. It's a nice little touch if you don't roleplay and you can't find your ship. Also stops you from having to load an earlier save, which can get a bit annoying in some games.
-The modify ship layout option. You can customize your ship to be whatever you want. Want every tile a holoscreen? Choose from 6 different tile types, including bathroom! Want a shit ton of barrels? Place items where ever you want and have as little or as much as you want. Scared of fires (and you should be)? You can put down a lotta fire extinguishers in a lotta places.
-The demo. Yeah before I sure wether or not to buy this I played the demo a lot. Also use the demo to test wether or not it will run on your pc. It was a pretty great demo and you can continue your game in the full version from where you left of in the demo.
-You can leave the controls whilst the ship moves. Wanna have a walk around your ship whilst on a long journey. Just press tab whilst steering your ship for it to continue on.
-First and third person mode. Wanna see what your pilot would see? Just hit f to switch to first person mode.
-The clutch controls are fun and they work well.
-Great soundtrack. Really fits the feel of the game.

So yeah 9/10. Go and buy it (but test it with the demo first, just incase it won't run for you). Looking forward to future updates!

17225789.review:
Rodina is sorta-kinda to space games what Kung Fury is to movies. Maybe that's being slightly too generous, but I guess I'm thinking in terms of direction. It's a throwback to a nostolgic art form that takes advantage of modern technology to produce something spectacular. Or at least, that's how you need to approach Rodina in order to appreciate it fairly. The truth is, anyone who is spoiled on Bioware games and the like complete with all interactions and audio feeds being fed to the player via *cough* audio may not like the fact that the storytelling in this game requires a lot of context switching from gameplay to patient reading. 

That said, the lore (which, again, must be read) is surprisingly well written, it's witty and sometimes filled with sarcastic humor while at other times helps immerse the player into the backstory of this universe. And by universe I mean solar system, and by solar system I mean planets surrounding a sun that themselves are surrounded by asteroid belts. And by this I mean you can seamlessly fly around to any of these and interact with them. No cutscenes. Everything is linear. There is travel scaling (such as "gears") so that you don't have to sit around for hours, but you're in complete control. You can land on an asteroid (which is where the game starts) or on a planet and get out of your ship and pick up ship upgrades, ammo, and electronic debris that typically contains radio transmissions that populate this lore I've already spoken too much of.

Learning how to play is apparently supposed to be part of the fun of playing. I found discovering the mappings with my Xbox 360 controller and/or tweaking them to be a slightly arduous learning process, but in the end I'm quite happy with gameplay controls. Changing gears using the controller while approaching soil by using a L-trigger + L-Joystick-Down combo is a rather scary, clunky process, but adds to the immersion, I suppose. Mapping to D-Pad up/down would be easier, but feel too arcade-ish.

Between landings, you must evade and/or fight alien sentry drones and other alien ships that are keeping a watchful eye over the planets and the loot. You're armed at first with a machine gun with infinite ammo, but as you pick up planetary loot you can equip other types of weaponry such as missiles and blaster guns. The game seems to support the Xbox 360 controller just fine, which has proven to be my favorite way to play the game, and let me just say that the space combat, while simple, is quite a blast. It's like the 1990s game Freespace, except less fluff, more action, and you can fly to planets and land and walk around, so Freespace has nothing on Rodina. 

The game performs a quicksave whenever something important happens such as entering atmosphere or entering battle, which is great because I hate having to redo things that I succeeded doing before. Speaking of "entering atmosphere", any time you approach a planetary surface you must sit through 60 or so seconds of your craft being on fire during entry. It dramatically adds immersion. Unfortunately, there aren't nearly enough things on the planet's surface going on to make atmospheric reentry a worthwhile game "feature", so it does get a bit old after the 20th landing for a loot pickup. 

You can walk around inside your ship, making the game feel a lot like a throwback notion of Star Trek at times, but with it being so big it feels rather lonely and non-interactive at times, since you really are all alone. There are some computer consoles you can interact with, but for the most part everything in your ship is Minecraft-style decor. There's a ship interior designer interface where you can redesign the rooms. I find all that distracting, to be honest. I'd rather more gameplay elements be added. 

Sometimes your ship can catch on fire (as in, the engine room or your bridge). When this happens, you have three options (that I've found). 1) load a savegame, try to avoid what caused it to happen [lame .. and I'm guilty of doing this most often], 2) grab a 20th century fire extinguisher hanging from the wall and try to put it out by hand (LOL .. honestly this is kind of funny, no ceiling mount sprinklers or anything?), or 3) if you're in space, run to an operations computer console and hit the Emergency Open All Doors button to let all the oxygen out. You yourself might get sucked out into space if you do this, so position yourself where you won't. It's a cool concept. This is GREAT content, by the way, the game author is on the right track!

I hope that people are buying this game and the creator(s) are building up some good cash flow to put back into the game because the help this game needs more content at this point than one person (or a small handful of people?) can do alone. That is to say, the game isn't a AAA game worth $59, but at $15 it is a wonderful way to spend an evening or two, way more interesting than a movie night at the theater.

Features I hope get added: flora, land creatures, body of self w/ switch to 3rd person view, some more complex space situations than drones and fighters (i.e. a mothership to take out Star Wars style), more interaction with the ship's interior objects, some "good guys" beyond lore to join the player as A.I., and multiplayer support.

The soundtrack quality is spectacular.

I'm guessing I'm only about a quarter or so into the "story", if you want to call it a "story" (again, it's a sandbox game with some lore delivery triggers as sequential radio transmission / journal pickups), but I can't help but wonder if my character is himself an android. How else am I out here on my own with no memory?

You would explore the galaxy, discover and explore stars and planets and, if you were the first there, name them. 17161879.review:
Rodina has a lot going for it; it could be one of the best space sims ever made, and it's not a complete game.

The controls are intuitive and easy to learn, which is remarkable.  I've played Elite: Dangerous and spent the first hour going in and out of the options screen.  I spent the first hour of Rodina exploring asteroids and planets and engaging Xenos in combat.

That's the best part here -- no lengthy tutorials, no flight schools, just jump into your ship and go.

The physics model is good, the stellar system is huge, and so far, it's a lot of fun to explore.  I can't wait to see what the developers will add, and add they must, because there's not much to do right now.

I would like to see less inertia in the physics model.  I like flying sideways and backwards, especially in combat, and I've noticed that downshifting from cruise mode to combat mode slows the ship down.  I would love it if the developers would implement zero gravity onboard the ship, but I don't expect that to happen.  Of all of science fiction, artificial gravity seems to be extremely commonplace, yet it is probably the most fictional element present.

Finally, what I'd really like to see is facilities that spawn NPCs, good and bad, and the ability for NPCs to expand operations by building more facilities.  If you want to wipe out the NPCs, you've got to wipe out the facilities that spawn them.  I recall playing Freelancer and Privateer and wondering how busy the shipyards must be as I cut my bloody path through space.

The bottom line, it's a great game, easy to play and lots of fun.  Let's hope they keep it that way!

NASA just flung a probe past Pluto and into the Kuiper belt. I couldn't even get off the first asteroid without killing myself.

If all of the recent space exploration hype has you itching to play a space game, I say skip the other titles that are currently available and go for Rodina. Sure Kerbal Space Program might be really complicated (and realistic?), but Rodina is a great little package for $15 that you can just pick up and play...and get addicted to. 

It has all the bells and whistles you'd want in a space sandbox game: Huge planets to explore, hundreds of asteroids to find and explore, logs that act kind of like journal entries that piece together a story, space combat, and more. I've only scratched the surface of the game (2.6 hours on record so far), and it's really mind blowing. I'm curious to see what else awaits me in the solar system.

17076805.review:
Did you see that trailer for No Man's Sky? Have that space exploration itch located in the most awkward spot? Well this is the closest thing you're going to find that can reach that itch.

Rodina is set in a single solar system Occupied by 4 life size planets, over 400 gigantic asteroids, and 15,000 tiny asteroids. All of them are teeming with loot, lore, and a hostile alien race. It is up to you to ensure that Humanity can colonize this new system safely before they arrive.

 In Rodina, your ship, is YOUR ship! You can set the layout of your ship however you want and furnish them as you please. Make your bedroom, bathroom, engineer room, and your bridge. There's even a Tile set made entirly of Holoscreens, which project the outside area on the walls in 3D, making it perfect for cockpits and/ or observation decks, so that you may gaze upon the stars. 

Space combat takes some getting used to, but very satisfying as you unleash hell on alien fighters and watch them hurl towards the surface of the planet in a fireball of glory! 

Space exploration is a tad bare bones at this time. You find a marker, destroy any hostiles gaurding it, land, grab the Datasticks (lore), Encryption Keys (story progress), and any special weapons ammo, and repeat. Although you can exit your ship, and explore the surounding terrain, theirs not much to see other than some amazing vistas on mountain tops and HUGE canyons. This is my only gripe in the game, however the Developer is very active in the community and is working on fleshing the game out.

Did i also mention Mod support? Can anyone say, kestral ship mod? :P

all in all, for $15 you're getting alot for whats available right now. This game is a little bare right now, but already has more heart and soul than any Triple A game that iv'e played in awhile. There's a 60 minute demo for you to try out, please try this game out, this is a must have for any space buff out there.

P.S. The soundtrack is amazing too. It feels like a mix of Intersteller and Firefly. ^_^

17069269.review:
After five hours of gameplay I can honestly say I am more hyped for rodina updates then I am for No Mans Sky... :P

Anyways. Rodina is a very nicely designed game, the only real loading screen you will encounter is loading a save.

Although there's not much to do currently, what you can do is done VERY well, flying feels smooth and combat is fluid and fun.

The ship can be customised from the ground up, including objects, it took me about a half hour to design my ship, you have a nice selection of tiles and things.

The modding scene is a nice size, with lots of custom ship models and interiors, though very few blocks, modeling for mods is done in blender, a free 3D modeling software.

Content is, like I said, limited, you can obtain ammo for 3 weapons (you start with all 3) and encounter 4 different enemy ships, none of which will use a weapon you can't.

Landing on a planet feels nice and is coupled with a fantastic soundtrack, atmospheric re-entry is nice and has a difficulty setting, I reccomed startng on 0.5 and slowly moving up from there.

Planets are planet sized, and asteroids are asteroid sized, which feels awsome!

All in all the game is amazing, heavy recommend.

Feel free to post opinions and corrections in the comments.

17059382.review:
Mr Developer,

I read the words 'Daggerfall in Space' and was sold. Daggerfall is one of the few oldies that I still play for more than nostalgia.

Rodina could very well be 'Daggerfall in Space'. It has the potential. I could see it within the first hour. With mod support, it could be something even greater. Or sillier. Beauty of mods.

But for the following couple of hours until I finished what is available of the main story line (I like to take my time), I am no longer sure I want it to be Daggerfall.

There is something about the atmosphere. The vastness of space at your fingertips. The lonliness of it all. It grew on me. I hunted the data cubes for scraps of story, for clues, for hope. Those close calls with me running to my ship followed by enemy fire. I fought the 'enemy' with purpose. I fought for revenge. For fallen comrades and the future of my people. I [b]wanted[/b] to. I also wanted to find a certain someone and slap them silly. I [b]really[/b] wanted to. But I don't want to spoil anything. I believe you did a phenominal job here.

If the game ends up being a vibrant universe with NPCs and bases to loot and first person combat and trade and whatever, I won't complain. I would be very happy. This would be a game that I would play for years to come.

But please, consider having a small side scenario. Call it an origin story, an electric dream (heh), whatever you want. Keep a small side scenario where I can play the lone wanderer in a vast space with no choice but to do the seemingly impossible.

Thank you for a great experience. Looking forward for more.

MBlueD

16686605.review:
June 24, 2015

This game is exceptional.  Given the fact, it is developed by a single person makes it all that more impressive.  The story is extremely engrossing.  The developer even went so far as to add secret story arcs that without a bit of deciphering would never be found.  And, the environments really paint a feeling of bleak lonliness in space.  The combat is fast-paced, but balanced and requires a fair amount of skill.  The difficulty ramps at just the right rate and the enemies are fun to fight.  Ship layouts are fully customizable and have an accessable interface to do so.  The developer is actively involved in the community and frequently seeks player input on the direction of development.

[strike]All this being said, there seems to be a memory leak somewhere causing my game to have frequent crashes.  However,[/strike] the auto-save feature is abundant [strike]and rarely have I felt my progress wasted.[/strike]

With no non-hostile NPCs, yet, it does leave me wanting.  It contributes to a lack of things to do within the game.  However, the developer has recently begun work on making the first non-hostile NPCs.

I would like to see more weapon options for the ship.  As well, I would like the option to eventually set up permanent bases on the planets.  Overall, I would like to see more to do.

Of all the early-access titles I have purchased, I feel most justified in paying full price for this one.  I'm honestly excited about development of this game.

[b]EDIT 7/6/2015:[/b]  Thanks to help from the developer, I was able to quickly resolve my crashing issue.  The speed of the dev's response was very fast and requires serious commendation. I look forward to many more hours playing Rodina.

16503388.review:
Okay, this game has some very VERY serious potential, and is already fun as it is.

The enviroment is one VERY large universe that has no loadtime at all because it is progressivly rendered (Like minecraft or kerbal space program). This makes it very engaging and immersive. This inside of your ship is completely customizable, and is also constantly rendered as your ship can take damage, start on fire, then the airlock can open and suddenly your sucked out into space. While the game is hard at first, it is easy to learn and fun to play. Totally negating any difficulty.

PROS:
>Beta game with exiting potential
>Fully customizable ship interior
>Progressivly rendered universe resulting in no loading screens
>Well programmed physics
>Immersive and vast

CONS:
(Please note that this game is still in early beta, and the cons listed are VERY likely to be fixed)
>Lack of much story (Though you can go to planets and collect data logs (journals), hinting the game will because story rich in the future.
>Only one player-controllable ship at this time
>Cannot enter enemy ships (I`m pretty sure there are plans to fix this though).
>No friendly NPCs, making the game feel lonely.

THINGS I WOULD LIKE TO SEE:
>Different types of player controllable ships
>Space stations and planitary space ports (can be used for repair, trade and autopilot navigation)
>More story, and of course, NPCs
>Upgradeable ships
>More options for customization, ie more things to put inside the ship (Space Engineers is an excellent reference)

There is more, but I`m sure most of it will happen eventually anyways. This game is Absolutely worth every penny.

10/10

16286068.review:
You are an astronaut trapped in a distant solar system with many questions and one very fast ship. You can land on any asteroid or stand atop any mountain, if you don't burn up in the atmosphere on your way down. Everything is rendered to scale with completely seamless transitions. There are enemies, but you can take them; there are mysteries, but they are just another excuse to go exploring. This is all so ambitious and novel that the game engine was developed completely from scratch, not out of hubris but because maintaining immersion at such variable scale simply isn't possible in any mainstream game engine.

It can only get better from here.

16245422.review:
This game is a gem. Rodina made me feel like a child, playing video games for the first time, again. The basic premise of the game is exploration. You're told you are the last survivor of an alien attack on a starship on which you were traveling. Rodina, the capital ship from which you're told you hail send you an urgent message that you need to gear up and prepare for battle, because you alone are meant to destroy the enormous alien presence in the solar system you now inhabit. As you set off from the asteroid you start on, you immediately discover that this solar system is massive. That it is home to more asteroids than you could imagine. You suddenly feel like you're truly, actually in space, in an alien solar system, far, far away from your home. The immersion factor of the cockpit mode and holoscreens make you feel like the interior of your ship and the exterior of your ship aren't disjointed anymore, like they once were before cockpit mode was introduced. You can now set your ship to cruise, get out of your pilot seat, walk around your ship, and all the while, your ship will continue flying without input, while you monitor its progression through windows (holoscreens). The very thought of it makes me giddy with excitement. The planets you discover, one by one, are each unique. Jarillo, in particular, stood out to me, because of its immense mountains, which make you feel so small when you're on its surface, though in a few short seconds you could be miles and miles above its surface, laughing down at the planet. Its things like that that make the game so wonderful, and mysterious. Rodina manages to keep you suspenseful the entire ride if you decide the pursue the story. And what a wonderful story it is. Alecja and Tavi's personal story is a heartwrencher, and you really get a feel for the other characters you get to know, not only through the encrypted communications you must decrypt, but also through the datasticks you find at every other debris field.

All in all, Rodina is a game that deserves your support. If you're a fan of space games, this is certainly a must buy. If you're a fan of exploration, Rodina has more exploration than you could imagine. If you enjoy blasting aliens, Rodina has a hefty amount of combat as well. If you enjoy a story that you must uncover yourself, and feel rewarded for doing so, then this will be a masterpiece for you, as it was for me. I greatly enjoy Rodina, and I can't wait for it to be developed even more.

16000637.review:
Rodina is an amazing experience for the price asked for. Seamless travel works very well, and the new holograms and cockpit mode are absolutely beautiful!

The biggest issue with the game are the limitations on how much there is to do. Go to every planet, fight some baddies, pick up ammo and datasticks full of (entertaining) readable info... but then... what?

The one thing that has had me coming back and back again has been the same thing that keeps me coming back for, say, Euro Truck Simulator: the beauty of the world you play in. Flying to the soundtrack is nothing short of amazing, admiring the beautiful glaciers, navigating a thick atmosphere in nighttime (terrifying, by the way). Knowing how to love the world keeps it fresh. Not only that, but the game is also in steady development. I can't wait to see what the future of this game holds.

Its worth the money now, it will be worth the money later. 

*recommends*

Ever wanted to explore the unknown reaches of space in a customizable, mansion-sized starship in order to unravel a mystery while simultaneously taking on a deadly alien armada???

Well, now you can!

Rodina is a very engaging game -- simple enough to learn in about a day, but filled to the brim with interesting things to do and see.  It offers an intriguing story, awesome hyperspace mechanics, atmospheric re-entry (too cool!), and combat that goes from simplistic to somewhat complex in a bit of a hurry.
